[('Yankees turn rare triple play against Orioles - USA TODAY', 'Debby Wong, USA TODAY SportsIn anything but ordinary fashion, the New York Yankees turned a triple play against the Baltimore Orioles.BOX SCORE: Yankees 5, Orioles 2With no outs and two men on base, Orioles third baseman Manny Machado stepped to the plate with a chance to get his team back in the game. Instead, Machado hit a hard grounder to second baseman Robinson Cano who tossed it to Jayson Nix at second base for the force. Nix, stepping in for an injured Eduardo Nunez at shortstop, caught Alexi Casilla in a rundown between second and third.After tagging Casilla, third baseman Kevin Youkilis throws back across the diamond to first baseman Lyle Overbay, where Machado is caught in a rundown between first and second. Cano then tagged Machado out at second, killing a potential rally.Score it 4-6-5-6-5-3-4, the first triple play of its kind in baseball history. It was just the Yankees second since 1969.The Yankees went on to beat the Orioles 5-2.Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/ZSahSj window.simpleExclusion = []; window.simpleTarget = [];  ', 'www.usatoday.com'), ('Triple play boosts Yankees over Orioles - USA TODAY', 'New York Yankees second baseman Robinson Cano tags out Baltimore Orioles third baseman Manny Machado to complete a triple play during the eighth inning at Yankee Stadium. Yankees won 5-2.(Photo: Debby Wong, USA TODAY Sports)Story HighlightsThe Yankees turned a triple play at home for the first time in 45 yearsAdam Jones dropped a Vernon Wells fly ball, setting off a three-run inningCC Sabathia allowed 2 runs and eight hits, and he struck out nine in the Yankees 5-2 victoryCONNECTTWEET                              1                      LINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORENEW YORK (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 Robinson Cano jumped up after applying the tag that completed a triple play and thrust his arms above his head. Kevin Youkilis grinned broadly and slapped as many hands as he could. Jayson Nix and Lyle Overbay high-fiving each other, too.The New York Yankees\' makeshift infield was having triple the fun Friday night.The Yankees turned a triple play at home for the first time in 45 years, Adam Jones dropped Vernon Wells\' fly ball while blowing a bubble for a tiebreaking three-run error and New York beat the Baltimore Orioles 5-2 Friday night for its fourth straight win.BOX SCORE: Yankees 5, Orioles 2"That\'s like being a kid again," Youkilis said. "That\'s one of the coolest things I\'ve ever had on the field. You don\'t see one written up like that. It was special. This game we play, it\'s one of these games where it\'s a job and it\'s a grind at times. But when stuff like that happens, you feel like you\'re back playing little league again."Baltimore started the eighth with two singles off CC Sabathia (2-1), and Manny Machado hit a sharp low liner that Cano caught on a short hop near second base.Cano tossed the ball to Nix, who replaced injured shortstop Eduardo Nunez in the third inning, for the forceout at second. Alexi Casilla, thinking the ball was going to be caught by Cano, got trapped in a rundown between second and third base.Thinking triple play, Youkilis tagged Casillas and made a quick throw to first baseman Lyle Overbay when Machado ranged too far off the bag. Overbay then made an awkward throw to Cano, who tagged Machado, setting off a happy celebration.Overbay, signed in late March to help fill in for injured first baseman Mark Teixeira, was worried his throw to Cano was going to spoil the play that was scored 4-6-5-6-5-3-4."Good thing he\'s got good hand-eye coordination," Overbay said.WILD PLAY: See how the Yanks did itTeixeira saw the team\'s hand specialist earlier Friday and was told he is not ready to start swinging a bat and needs to strengthen his injured wrist. But Teixeira said this is not a setback and should be on target for a return near May 1.The five-time Gold Glover was impressed with his teammates."That was awesome," Teixeira said. "That\'s one of the toughest triple plays you\'ll ever see."The Yankees, who moved over .500 for the first time this year, had last turned a triple play on April 22, 2010, at Oakland \xe2\x80\x94 with Sabathia on the mound. They hadn\'t accomplished the feat in the Bronx since June 3, 1968, against Minnesota.With the score 2-all in the seventh, the Yankees had loaded the bases on two walks \xe2\x80\x94 one intentional \xe2\x80\x94 and a hit batter. Wells hit a long fly ball that Jones \xe2\x80\x94 a Gold Glove center fielder \xe2\x80\x94 ranged back for. On the warning track, Jones turned, raised his glove and blew a pink bubble. He closed his glove a bit early, and the ball bounced away as the bases cleared."Just missed it," Jones said. "You could say it\'s rain. You could say it\'s cold. You could say anything, wind, you could say whatever you want. I was there. Didn\'t catch it. Cost my team the game."In the first meeting between the teams since the Yankees eliminated the Orioles in Game 5 of the division series, Sabathia allowed two runs \xe2\x80\x94 one earned \xe2\x80\x94 and eight hits with nine strikeouts and no walks. Mariano Rivera pitched the ninth for his second save.Youkilis had three hits and an RBI but made an error at third base that led to the tying run in the seventh inning. Youkilis has hit in all nine games he\'s played with the Yankees."Made an aggressive mistake," Youkilis said. "You just don\'t want to give away outs."Baltimore tied it 2-all when Matt Wieters reached on Youkilis\' misplay and advanced on Sabathia\'s balk. J.J. Hardy followed with an RBI single.Already hampered by several key injuries, the Yankees pushed back Andy Pettitte\'s scheduled start Sunday in the finale of this three-game series to Tuesday or Wednesday because of back spasms. Phil Hughes, whose scheduled start Thursday was postponed by rain, will get the ball Saturday and Hiroki Kuroda will move back one day to Sunday.Too make matters worse for New York, Nunez, filling in at shortstop for injured captain Derek Jeter, was hit on his right wrist by a pitch from Miguel Gonzalez (1-1) and left after attempting a warmup throw before the third inning.X-rays were negative.Gonzalez dropped No. 9 hitter Francisco Cervelli to the dirt in the fifth with a pitch that came close to the catcher\'s head, and the right-hander was booed relentlessly by what remained of the 35,033 fans that withstood the blustery 35-degree wind chill.Cervelli ended up walking and coming around to score \xe2\x80\x94 clapping his hands \xe2\x80\x94 on Cano\'s RBI single to left-center, his eighth RBI in three games."Miguel, I don\'t think he felt the baseball. He didn\'t really have a feel for his curveball most of the game," Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. "It was frustrating for him, but CC had a good outing, did a lot of things he\'s been doing for a long time. He\'s a pitcher. Miguel gave us a chance to win the game. We were fortunate not to give up more damage than we did."NOTES: Gonzalez walked five. ... Jeter (ankle surgery) took batting practice on the field and grounders at the Yankees minor league complex in Tampa, Fla. He did a few slower-speed spin moves on balls up the middle. ... The Orioles claimed RHP Alex Burnett off waivers from Toronto and optioned him to Triple-A Rochester. To make room on the 40-man roster, they transferred INF Wilson Betemit (torn right knee ligament) from the 15- to the 60-day DL. ... Orioles RHP Steve Johnson (lat strain) and LHP Tsuyoshi Wada (elbow surgery) are to throw in extended spring training Saturday. ... Youkilis\' hitting streak is the longest to start a season for a player in his Yankees debut since Joe Buzzas had hits in the first 10 games of 1945, according to information provided by the Yankees from the Elias Sports Bureau.CONNECTTWEET                              1                      LINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORECopyright 2013 The Associated Press. ', 'www.usatoday.com'), ('Orioles claim some guy on waivers from Blue Jays - Camden \\u2026', ' What do you do if you have a designated hitter who\'s recovering from a torn PCL, you just traded a right-handed reliever, and another right-handed reliever with a minor league option becomes available on waivers? Because we watched him in action last season, we already know what is the answer for Orioles Executive Vice President of Baseball Operations Dan Duquette. Claim him on waivers, send him to Norfolk, and hope you never need him. The player in question is Alex Burnett, who was designated for assignment by the Blue Jays when they claimed Towson University product Casper Wells. Burnett had been sent to the great DFA in the sky by the Twins at the end of spring training, so he\'s got to be feeling a little unwanted by now. Duquette wants him, though, at least for a little while. I wouldn\'t look into any long-term leases. Wilson Betemit has been transferred to the 60-day disabled list to make a spot on the 40-man roster. Sometimes, I can tell what is the rationale for these random roster moves based on the content of the press release the Orioles send out about them. For instance, when a lefty pitcher is claimed, they will often mention his splits against lefty batters. In the case of Burnett, here is what they said: he\'s 25 with a 4.61 ERA (170 IP, 87 ER) in 174 major league games with the Twins, has a 3.40 ERA (522 IP, 197 ER) in eight minor league seasons, mostly all with the Twins, and was a 12th round pick in 2005.    Should Duquette address the media about this claim, he\'ll probably string together some phrases from his book of stock phrases. Maybe a little something like this: "Alex Burnett is a qualified major league pitcher, a dependable reliever with years of big league service who has excelled in retiring right-handed batters from the bullpen. We had the opportunity to add him to our organization and we believe he will provide depth to our ball club by pitching out of the Norfolk bullpen." He may surprise us all and say something else, or he may say nothing at all, because all the beat reporters are on the road in New York and they don\'t have time to write about the latest random waiver claim in any sort of detail.  ', 'www.camdenchat.com'), ('Former Orioles Great Ken Singleton Talks Early Season ...', '  Former Baltimore Oriole Ken Singleton ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com')]

[('In A.L. East, 90 Wins May Be Enough - The New York Times', '     Supported by    Baseball  Early Signs of Parity in A.L. East, Where 90 Wins May Be Enough    On Baseball  By                       TYLER KEPNER   APRIL 13, 2013     Continue reading the main story Share This Page  Continue reading the main story                if (             window.magnum             && window.magnum.getFlags().indexOf(\'headlineBalancer\') > 0             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.shouldRun()         ) {             window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize();         }        The Baltimore Orioles unloaded on Phil Hughes on Saturday, hitting him so hard for three innings that Hughes said he could not remember the last time he had pitched so badly. Maybe there were better times to ask Hughes about the strength of the division, times when he could have been more objective. But his perspective seemed to sum up the new reality of the American League East.\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen as much talent in the division as there is right now,\xe2\x80\x9d Hughes said after the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 5-3 loss in the Bronx. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody seemed to improve from last year, bringing guys in from elsewhere. It seems like there\xe2\x80\x99s much more difficult lineups, top to bottom, with how balanced they are. Guys are coming off the bench that would be starting other places. It\xe2\x80\x99s just a very deep division.\xe2\x80\x9dThe start of the season has, for now, confirmed the general suspicion. The tattered Yankees and their collection of former stars have a .500 record after Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s loss. Every team in the division has four to six victories. The sample is so small that it might be meaningless, but it is all we have, and it indicates the possibility of a different kind of A.L. East.In the last 12 seasons, the division champions have averaged 98 victories and never had fewer than 95. This year, it seems, 90 wins might do it, even if the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 manager, Buck Showalter, disagrees. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cI think that would be hard to do,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe think we have a corner on playing competitively in the A.L. East, but it\xe2\x80\x99s tough in the West, it\xe2\x80\x99s tough in the Central. You try to stay focused on your group, and you know that you\xe2\x80\x99re going to have to be around that 90 mark to be even in the hunt. I think that still holds true.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 Lyle Overbay, who played five seasons for Toronto, was cut by Boston this spring. Overbay said the new Red Sox manager, John Farrell, would help starters Jon Lester and Clay Buchholz, who are 4-0 in five starts. To Overbay, the pitching seems deeper in the division, and thus the teams are better.\xe2\x80\x9cIt used to be the Yankees and Red Sox, and then Tampa got into the mix,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cNow you\xe2\x80\x99ve got Baltimore, and Toronto went out and made all those moves, too. There\xe2\x80\x99s not a weak team in this division. It\xe2\x80\x99s like playoff teams, consistently. There\xe2\x80\x99s no room for mistakes.\xe2\x80\x9dThe first major mistake of the regular season may have come Friday night at Kansas City, when Toronto\xe2\x80\x99s Jose Reyes slid awkwardly into second base and severely sprained his ankle. The Blue Jays placed Reyes on the disabled list Saturday, and General Manager Alex Anthopoulos told Toronto reporters that Reyes would miss three months. Photo       Jose Reyes, in his first season with the Blue Jays, injured his ankle Friday on a steal attempt. Toronto placed him on the disabled list Saturday and said he might miss three months.  Credit             Dave Kaup/Reuters           The Blue Jays are still without third baseman Brett Lawrie because of a rib cage injury, and they called up shortstop Munenori Kawasaki from Class AAA to take Reyes\xe2\x80\x99s spot on the roster. They also have the veteran utility man Maicer Izturis, signed for three years and $10 million last winter, as insurance.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody goes through a period where some key guys are not there, and it\xe2\x80\x99s how you handle those things,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cI know Toronto, and Izturis is a good player; they paid well for him. I expect they\xe2\x80\x99ll do just fine.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Even if Reyes were playing, he could do little to change the Blue Jays\xe2\x80\x99 biggest weakness. The rotation was supposed to be sturdy after adding R. A. Dickey, Mark Buehrle and Josh Johnson. But it started play Saturday with a 7.55 earned run average, by far the highest in the major leagues. The Blue Jays\xe2\x80\x99 best starter has been J. A. Happ, who replaced the former All-Star Ricky Romero when Romero was banished to the minors. Privacy Policy    The Orioles have been a bit shaky, too, with a 4.79 starters\xe2\x80\x99 E.R.A., but they are into their third time through the rotation without making a change. That is significant for a team that churned through 12 starters last season, including only one who made more than 20 starts.The Orioles were due some good luck last season and got it with a 29-9 record in one-run games. As if to prove that such a pace was unsustainable, the Orioles lost their first three one-run games this season.But rotation stability \xe2\x80\x94 and the potential for a high-impact addition with the top prospect Dylan Bundy \xe2\x80\x94 is one reason to be optimistic about the Orioles. Another is a full season of Manny Machado, a 21-year-old third baseman.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Machado was the third overall pick in the 2010 draft, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 reward for losing 98 games under Dave Trembley the year before. A shortstop for all but two games in the minors, Machado deftly handled a position switch in the middle of a pennant race late last summer.\xe2\x80\x9cHe understood, when he came up here, that he was going to have some ups and downs,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut he can always impact the game at third base, and he\xe2\x80\x99s done that.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Machado finished Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s game by retiring Kevin Youkilis on a routine grounder, evening the series after the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 victory on Friday. The finale will play to a national audience Sunday night, suggesting that these two teams are the marquee entries in baseball\xe2\x80\x99s murkiest division. The reality is more complicated and could take a long time to reveal itself. Take him ouuuuuut!\xe2\x80\x9d He was louder with each hard hit. Soon, a few others started to boo. By the fourth, as Hughes walked off the mound with his head bowed after being removed from the game, the crowd was more decided.\xe2\x80\x9cBoooooooo!\xe2\x80\x9d they let out, louder now, deeper, in unison.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m used to it \xe2\x80\x94 unfortunately,\xe2\x80\x9d Hughes said after the Baltimore Orioles had pummeled him and beat the Yankees, 5-3. He let out a nervous laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s something you deal with when you\xe2\x80\x99re not playing well.\xe2\x80\x9dHughes certainly did not pitch well. He allowed five runs, nine hits (including three home runs) and two walks in three-plus innings. The outing went so poorly that Manager Joe Girardi had to affirm Hughes\xe2\x80\x99s spot in the rotation, after his second start of the season.Before the game, Girardi said he wondered how sharp Hughes would be. He had pitched seven days ago, the long layoff the result of back-to-back postponements in Cleveland last week. In that start, the Tigers had battered him for four runs in four innings. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      If Hughes was going to lack polish Saturday, Girardi indicated it would show early on.On cue, Hughes allowed a leadoff double and issued two four-pitch walks in the first inning, but he escaped allowing just one run. In the second, he gave up a towering home run to Ryan Flaherty, who had struck out in 9 of his 18 at-bats this season.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  In the third, Nick Markakis sent a fastball deep into the right-field seats, and a lone voice from the stands called for Hughes to come out. Then Adam Jones singled, Chris Davis doubled, and two batters later, Jones scored.When Nolan Reimold, the No. 9 hitter, crushed another fastball for a home run to start the fourth, and Nate McLouth hit the next fastball for a double, Girardi made his way to the mound. Hughes was pulled, and he went back to the clubhouse to watch the rest of the game.On the field, Girardi called for David Phelps, and he proceeded to strike out four of the first five Orioles he faced. He was as effective and sharp as Hughes was not. Phelps lasted four innings, allowed one hit, a single, and struck out six.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Girardi said it was too soon to consider swapping Phelps for Hughes in the rotation. It would not be fair this early in the season, Girardi said. Photo       Francisco Cervelli tagged out Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s Nate McLouth in the second inning on Saturday. He was trying to score on a two-out single to right by Manny Machado.  Credit             Uli Seit for The New York Times           Hughes addressed reporters at his locker. He said he was healthy, that this ineptness had nothing to do with the bulging disk in his back that he dealt with in spring training. He wished he could explain why his career earned run average in March and April was above 7.00.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t remember the last time I was as bad as that,\xe2\x80\x9d Hughes said. \xe2\x80\x9cJust not being able to locate the fastball, or any off-speed pitch, for that matter. Anytime I did have to come in for a strike, it was over the middle of the plate and just got hammered somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9dHe added, \xe2\x80\x9cEverything I can remember was out, up, over the plate, and that\xe2\x80\x99s what\xe2\x80\x99s going to happen.\xe2\x80\x9d [{"headline":"Sports","summary":"Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, delivered to your inbox every week.","product-code":"SP","product-title":"Sports","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/sports?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=SP&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Race\\/Related Newsletter","summary":"Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with New York Times journalists.","product-code":"RR","product-title":"Race Related","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/race-related?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=RR&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Your Money","summary":"Every week, get tips on retirement, paying for college, credit cards and the right way to invest.","product-code":"MY","product-title":"Your Money","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/your-money?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=business&contentId=MY&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"}]      Please verify you\'re not a robot by clicking the box. Privacy Policy    Phelps arrived at the locker next to Hughes, and television cameras turned to him. He was asked about potentially being moved into the rotation.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m happy with where I\xe2\x80\x99m at, just to help the team in whatever role it may be,\xe2\x80\x9d Phelps said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not out here hoping our starters don\xe2\x80\x99t do well.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  But he was a traditional starter, one who posted a 3.77 E.R.A. in 11 starts last season.Hughes said of Phelps: \xe2\x80\x9cHe was great, the whole bullpen, really kept us in the game. It shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been close, to be honest.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Yankees kept it close early. Travis Hafner led off the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 second with a home run and Francisco Cervelli hustled to second base on a throwing error by J. J. Hardy, scoring when Lyle Overbay hit a soft fly ball that fell in shallow left center to tie the score, 2-2.But Hughes did not hold the lead for long, allowing three runs in the next two innings. Vernon Wells got a run back with a home run in the sixth, and the Yankees had two runners on with one out. But the Orioles escaped the inning.In the ninth, Robinson Cano went to shortstop for Jayson Nix, who was pulled for a pinch hitter, and Cervelli shifted to second. It was the first time in his major league career Cano had played any position other than second base.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Hughes watched all this from the clubhouse, his day long over.Inside PitchJoe GiRardi said that Alex Rodriguez surprised him by showing up for Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s game, watching it from the dugout. Girardi said Rodriguez, recovering from off-season hip surgery, told him he that he was able to get on a treadmill the other day. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was pretty fired up about that,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. Dickey Wins First as Blue Jays Beat Royals APRIL 14, 2013                       ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('4/13: Birds Watcher- Musings of a Misplaced Orioles Fan', 'Apr 7, 2013; Baltimore, MD, USA; Baltimore Orioles first baseman Chris Davis (19) at bat in the seventh inning against the Minnesota Twins at Oriole Park at Camden Yards. The Twins defeated the Orioles 4 \xe2\x80\x93 3. Mandatory Credit: Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY SportsThe 2013 season is officially 11 games old, with the Orioles standing at 6-5, and how many games have this California-based Orioles fan seen? Zero. I follow Orioles news on Twitter, so I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen the heralds of Chris Davis after his amazing start, four homers in the first four games, but I also quickly see the bad news like Davis\xe2\x80\x99s error in game five and Adam Jones\xe2\x80\x98s error in last night\xe2\x80\x99s loss to the Yankees. Because the Orioles got off to such a surprisingly hot start last season, they were all over the sporting news and that was music to my misplaced fan heart. I was able to reconnect with the team I\xe2\x80\x99d grown up rooting for, just now I was doing it from 3,000 miles away. This year, with the .500 start and the endless reports of PEDs (again) and the recent \xe2\x80\x9cbase-brawl\xe2\x80\x9d between the Dodgers & Padres, among other headlines, news about the Orioles hasn\xe2\x80\x99t popped up as often and I have suddenly encountered the conundrum that faces many sports fans; my team is doing well but I don\xe2\x80\x99t live near them anymore so I\xe2\x80\x99ve found myself out of the loop.March 30, 2013; Sarasota, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles catcher Matt Wieters (32) against the New York Mets at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Kim Klement-USA TODAY SportsI am certainly not the first person ever to face this dilemma. I moved from Baltimore when I was 12 because of my dad\xe2\x80\x99s job, but because it ended up being another 12 years until the Orioles had a winning record, I never felt like I was missing anything. It feels somewhat sacrilegious to say that, but the ups and downs of those 15 years left this Orioles fan a bit bruised, so my cheering had developed a healthy dose of skepticism. That being said, watching fans find their way back to Camden Yards last season as the team began to succeed again was amazing; it felt like the beginning of a new chapter, a really good chapter for a team like the Orioles with such a storied history.I know sports fans move cities for various reasons all the time, but living in California as a baseball fan means that I\xe2\x80\x99m in the minority and surrounded by lots of Giants, Padres, Athletics, Dodgers, & Angels. Whenever I turn on the TV, those are the uniforms I see along with names like Barry Zito, Matt Kemp & Albert Pujols. Don\xe2\x80\x99t get me wrong, it\xe2\x80\x99s a fun experience to live in the city home to the most recent World Series champions, but they are not the team I cheer for, that\xe2\x80\x99s the Orioles. I want to see Adam Jones rob someone of a home run in center field, Matt Wieters\xc2\xa0throw out a runner at 2nd base with ease,\xc2\xa0Chris Davis clear the bases with one swing of his bat, and Jim Johnson strike out the side in the 9th inning. I\xe2\x80\x99m a recent college graduate, so it\xe2\x80\x99s not really in my budget to invest in MLB network, and I\xe2\x80\x99m on the phone during the day at work so much that it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to justify paying to listen to the games on the radio because I probably wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be able to do that anyway.March 25, 2013; Sarasota, FL, USA; Baltimore Orioles relief pitcher Jim Johnson (43) throws a pitch during the sixth inning against the Boston Red Sox at Ed Smith Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Kim Klement-USA TODAY SportsI do my best to catch highlights on the late-night Sportscenter or baltimoreorioles.com but there\xe2\x80\x99s so much I feel like I\xe2\x80\x99m missing! There\xe2\x80\x99s no use in complaining about it because I enjoy living in California AND I enjoy being an Orioles fan. I also root for the Ravens, so I feel like I\xe2\x80\x99ve been spoiled because their prolonged success, especially their recent Super Bowl victory, has kept them consistently in the public eye (and on national TV). The Orioles are just beginning their ascent back to success, but it won\xe2\x80\x99t happen overnight. Fans can see the ebbs & flows continuously throughout the season through social media outlets like Facebook, Twitter, & Vine, but there is something to be said for going to the stadium on a muggy summer night or sitting in front of the TV with friends watching a game, it feels timeless. This post may be coming at the completely wrong time since the Orioles are scheduled to play primetime Sunday Night Baseball tomorrow against the Yankees \xf0\x9f\x99\x82 but since the season is a marathon, not a sprint,\xc2\xa0I wanted to pose the question, what should I do? Help this Orioles fan get back in the loop! ', 'birdswatcher.com'), ('Yankees turn triple play in win over Orioles - yahoo.com', 'View photosNew York Yankees third baseman Kevin Youkilis, left, tags out Baltimore Orioles\' Alexi Casilla for the second out of a triple play during the eight inning of a baseball game at Yankee Stadium in New York, Friday, April 12, 2013. (AP Photo/Julio Cortez)MoreNEW YORK (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 They\'ve heard the "Who\'s on first jokes?" They\'ve barely played together as a group. Still, there they were, the New York Yankees infield high-fiving and smiling with glee after having turned a most improbable triple play."That was awesome," injured first baseman Mark Teixeira said Friday night after the Yankees\' 5-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. "That\'s one of the toughest triple plays you\'ll ever see."And how. For those scoring at home, mark it as a 4-6-5-6-5-3-4 in your books.Put names to the numbers and it won\'t be Derek Jeter at shortstop, Alex Rodriguez at third base or Teixeira at first. Jayson Nix, filling in for the fill-in shortstop, Kevin Youkilis at third base and Lyle Overbay on first completed the Yankees\' first triple play in the Bronx in 45 years.Baltimore started the eighth inning with singles by Alexi Casilla and Nick Markakis off CC Sabathia (2-1). Manny Machado then hit a sharp low liner that Robinson Cano caught on a short hop near second base. Cano threw to Nix, who entered in the third for Eduardo Nunez, at second for the forceout.Casilla, thinking the ball was going to be caught by Cano, got trapped in a rundown between second and third base.Youkilis tagged Casilla and made a quick throw to Overbay when Machado ranged too far off the bag. Overbay then made an awkward throw to Cano, who tagged Machado, setting off a celebration."That\'s like being a kid again," Youkilis said. "That\'s one of the coolest things I\'ve ever had on the field. You don\'t see one written up like that. It was special. This game we play, it\'s one of these games where it\'s a job and it\'s a grind at times. But when stuff like that happens, you feel like you\'re back playing Little League again."Overbay, signed in late March to help fill in for Teixeira, was worried his throw to Cano was going to spoil the effort."Good thing he\'s got good hand-eye coordination," Overbay said.The Yankees, who moved over .500 for the first time this year, had last turned a triple play on April 22, 2010, at Oakland \xe2\x80\x94 with Sabathia on the mound. They hadn\'t accomplished the feat in the Bronx since June 3, 1968, against Minnesota.The Orioles\' had not hit into a triple play since April 3, 1996, against Kanas City."The two lead runners made the right play," Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. "It\'s a line drive short-hop. You can\'t go anywhere because if he catches it, then he does get multiple outs. We just made a mistake on the trail runner trying to get a little overaggressive, a young player."Teixeira saw the team\'s hand specialist earlier Friday and was told he is not ready to start swinging a bat and needs to strengthen his injured wrist. But Teixeira said this is not a setback and he should be on target for a return near May 1. Jeter is rehabilitating his broken ankle in Florida and A-Rod is rehabbing from hip surgery and might not return until after the All-Star break.The Yankees got some help from Gold Glove center fielder Adam Jones in beating the Orioles.With the score 2-all in the seventh, the Yankees had loaded the bases on two walks \xe2\x80\x94 one intentional \xe2\x80\x94 and a hit batter. Vernon Wells, another late-March acquisition, hit a long fly ball that Jones ranged back for. On the warning track, Jones turned, raised his glove and blew a pink bubble. He closed his glove a bit early, and the ball bounced away as the bases cleared."Just missed it," Jones said. "You could say it\'s rain. You could say it\'s cold. You could say anything, wind, you could say whatever you want. I was there. Didn\'t catch it. Cost my team the game."In the first meeting between the teams since the Yankees eliminated the Orioles in Game 5 of the division series, Sabathia allowed two runs \xe2\x80\x94 one earned \xe2\x80\x94 and eight hits with nine strikeouts and no walks. Mariano Rivera pitched the ninth for his second save.Youkilis had three hits and an RBI but made an error at third base that led to the tying run in the seventh inning. Youkilis has hit in all nine games he\'s played with the Yankees."Made an aggressive mistake," Youkilis said. "You just don\'t want to give away outs."Baltimore tied it 2-all when Matt Wieters reached on Youkilis\' misplay and advanced on Sabathia\'s balk. J.J. Hardy followed with an RBI single.Nunez was hit on his right wrist by a pitch from Miguel Gonzalez (1-1) and left after attempting a warmup throw before the third inning.X-rays were negative.Gonzalez dropped No. 9 hitter Francisco Cervelli to the dirt in the fifth with a pitch that came close to the catcher\'s head, and the right-hander was booed relentlessly by what remained of the 35,033 fans that withstood the blustery 35-degree wind chill.Cervelli ended up walking and coming around to score \xe2\x80\x94 clapping his hands \xe2\x80\x94 on Cano\'s RBI single to left-center, his eighth RBI in three games.NOTES: Gonzalez walked five. ... The Orioles claimed RHP Alex Burnett off waivers from Toronto and optioned him to Triple-A Rochester. To make room on the 40-man roster, they transferred INF Wilson Betemit (torn right knee ligament) from the 15- to the 60-day DL. ... Youkilis\' hitting streak is the longest to start a season for a player in his Yankees debut since Joe Buzzas had hits in the first 10 games of 1945, according to information provided by the Yankees from the Elias Sports Bureau. ', 'www.yahoo.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();  It has been six months since the Yankees edged the Baltimore Orioles in the American League division series, although in many respects, for the winners, it has felt like six awfully long years.The team is slowly returning to full health, in piecemeal fashion, and only one player (Robinson Cano) who started in last season\xe2\x80\x99s Game 5 for the Yankees in the A.L.D.S. was in the lineup Sunday night.But with this cast of fill-ins \xe2\x80\x94 a Band-Aid unit in a patchwork lineup \xe2\x80\x94 the Yankees have managed to stay above .500 through the first 11 games of the season, at 6-5. The offense has looked reliable, just productive enough. And with a 3-0 win over the Orioles at Yankee Stadium, they showed they could still pitch the way they did in early October.Baltimore returned largely the same lineup from their postseason run, which ended on a damp and windswept afternoon with a shutdown performance from the Yankees ace C. C. Sabathia. The result Sunday \xe2\x80\x94 if not the temperature, which was chillier \xe2\x80\x94 was remarkably reminiscent. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Instead of Sabathia, it was Hiroki Kuroda who blanked the Orioles with a complete-game shutout, the fifth of his career. Kuroda allowed only five hits and no walks while striking out five \xe2\x80\x94 a masterly performance that quelled any lingering questions about how he might fare in a second full season in the Bronx.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Kuroda, a 38-year-old right-hander, left his first start of the season in the second inning, after injuring his hand, and lasted only five and a third innings in his second. But on Sunday, Kuroda was almost untouchable, not letting an Orioles runner reach second base until the ninth inning, allowing only seven base runners in all.\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s fun to catch,\xe2\x80\x9d catcher Francisco Cervelli said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s able to throw any pitch whenever he wants in the place he wants.\xe2\x80\x9dKuroda said, \xe2\x80\x9cAgainst righties and lefties, I was really able to get my sinker going.\xe2\x80\x9dIn the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 first nationally televised Sunday night game since Sept. 21, 2008 \xe2\x80\x94 the final regular-season game at the old Yankee Stadium \xe2\x80\x94 they looked as if they were ready to just get out of the cold weather. Photo       The Yankees scored all of their runs in the fifth inning, two on Brett Gardner\xe2\x80\x99s homer.  Credit             Al Bello/Getty Images           The middle of Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s order \xe2\x80\x94 Nick Markakis, Adam Jones and Chris Davis \xe2\x80\x94 combined to go 2 for 12 with 4 strikeouts. The Orioles grounded out 18 times, and the final 17 batters to face Kuroda got just one hit.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Yankees got on the board in the fifth inning against Wei-Yin Chen, with a sacrifice fly by Jayson Nix scoring Brennan Boesch, who had singled to lead off the inning. Brett Gardner then drilled a two-run homer off the right-field foul pole to give the Yankees a 3-0 lead. The bottom of the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 order, which is not all that different from the top or the middle, went 5 for 10 and scored two runs.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  And somehow, some way, the Yankees are third in the American League with 60 runs and second with 18 home runs. Entering Sunday, the six players who joined the Yankees this off-season \xe2\x80\x94 five of whom were in the lineup \xe2\x80\x94 were batting .306 with 10 of the team\xe2\x80\x99s 17 home runs and 27 of the team\xe2\x80\x99s 51 runs driven in. Privacy Policy    \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve shown their character,\xe2\x80\x9d Manager Joe Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cGuys have stepped up and done a good job in people\xe2\x80\x99s absences.\xe2\x80\x9dOne of the team\xe2\x80\x99s mainstays, Curtis Granderson, was in the clubhouse before the game, and tentatively said that he expects to return to the lineup from a fractured right forearm by early May.Granderson, who has been recovering in Tampa, Fla., has begun throwing and fielding but has yet to swing a bat. He is likely to need a long rehabilitation assignment as well, considering he was injured during his first at-bat of spring training in February.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  But his appearance in front of his locker in the deep left corner of the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 clubhouse was an uplifting sight. So were his comments on Derek Jeter, who is also rehabilitating in Tampa and who, according to Granderson, has been spraying the ball \xe2\x80\x9call over the place\xe2\x80\x9d during batting practices.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The crew may be rounding into shape, piece by piece. After a 1-4 start, the Yankees have managed to fight back to respectability. There was even a hint of some hopefulness in the Bronx on Sunday night, not really felt since October.\xe2\x80\x9cOur guys have done very well and have responded very well to a slow start,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m happy with what these guys have done so far.\xe2\x80\x9dINSIDE PITCHThe Yankees left-hander ANDY PETTITTE had his start pushed back a second time to Friday because of back spasms. Pettitte was originally scheduled to pitch Tuesday. Infielder EDUARDO NUNEZ (right wrist contusion) said he would swing a bat Monday in hopes of returning to the lineup Tuesday after missing two games. [('Baltimore Orioles looking forward to getting back to ...', '/* Javascript deferred */var addthis_options = "digg, twitter, facebook, stumbleupon, delicious, friendfeed, buzz, slashdot, reddit, mixx, fark, linkedin, aim, google, myspace, newsvine, technorati, tumblr, typepad, wordpress, more";var addthis_exclude = "print";var addthis_pub     = "archivedigger";/* Javascript deferred */Orioles looking forward to getting back to Camden YardsApril 15, 2013|By Eduardo A. Encina | The Baltimore SunI\xe2\x80\x99m currently on the Amtrak heading home from New York. I\xe2\x80\x99ve slept in my own bed for just two nights since Feb. 10, so heading back to Baltimore for the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 nine-game homestand will be a welcome change.The Orioles played nine of their first 12 games on the road, opening the season in Tampa Bay before this week\xe2\x80\x99s road trip to Boston and New York. So they\xe2\x80\x99ve only been home for three games since the beginning of spring training.During the opening two weeks of the season, the Orioles have also played games at five different start times and played in three Opening Day games, which has prevented them from setting up any sense of routine after a spring training full of early afternoon games. var adSkipCounter = 0; \xe2\x80\x9cI think just from getting on a schedule and on a clock it\xe2\x80\x99s been a challenge,\xe2\x80\x9d Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s been a challenge and with the WBC and all the things that have kind of been discombobulated with the schedule.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been proud with the way they\xe2\x80\x99ve handled it, but that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean you\xe2\x80\x99re going to go home and play better or worse. It\xe2\x80\x99s more just getting your life in order a little bit. I think everybody is looking forward to some type of schedule if there\xe2\x80\x99s such a thing in baseball. I don\xe2\x80\x99t hear our guys complaining about it. It\xe2\x80\x99s just a part of the job description.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Orioles come out of this stretch 6-6, which isn\xe2\x80\x99t particularly great, but considering they earned series wins in Tampa Bay and Boston, it will do.But now that the Orioles come home to face the Rays, Dodgers and Blue Jays, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that everything is rosy. Keep in mind that last year\xe2\x80\x99s Orioles team flourished on the road, leading the American League with 46 wins away from Camden Yards.\xe2\x80\x9cOur guys would like to be 12-0,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd believe me, I know that sounds clich\xc3\xa9-ish. Does it mean that now everything\xe2\x80\x99s going to be OK and we\xe2\x80\x99re going to win all of our games at home? No, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean anything.\xe2\x80\x9dThe schedule doesn\xe2\x80\x99t get any easier following this homestand, as the Orioles head west for 11 games in 11 days in Seattle, Oakland and Anaheim that takes them through the first weekend in May.\xe2\x80\x9cI bet you can go into any clubhouse and they\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you that there\xe2\x80\x99s some part of the schedule that\xe2\x80\x99s really challenging,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen we get through with this, we\xe2\x80\x99re going to head out to the West Coast with no off day. What are you gonna do? Quit? ', 'articles.baltimoresun.com'), ("A look at the baseball heroes of '42' on Jackie Robinson Day", 'From left: Spider Jorgenson, Pee Wee Reese, Eddie Stanky and Jackie Robinson. (PHOTO: AP Photo)The themes of the new movie 42, a biopic about Robinson that dominated the weekend box office, extend beyond the baseball field upon which they largely take place.But because baseball \xe2\x80\x93 as noted early in the film \xe2\x80\x93 comes with exhaustive and "democratic" records of player performance, we can measure the on-field accomplishments of the players depicted as heroes in the movie even while appreciating their more important roles in integrating the game. So, with the help of baseball-reference.com, here\'s a look at the playing careers of the film\'s most notable good guys (or improved guys).Jackie Robinson: One of the first scenes of 42 shows Dodgers general manager Branch Rickey selecting Robinson\'s resume from a pile of scouting reports on Negro League players due to his age and attitude. But Rickey\'s scouting triumph in inviting Robinson to break baseball\'s color barrier is perhaps overlooked. At that point, obviously, there was no sure way to know how Negro League performance would translate to the Majors, or how baseball history \xe2\x80\x93 and for that matter, American history \xe2\x80\x93 would have changed if Robinson couldn\'t hack it in the big leagues. Luckily for all involved, he could: Though Robinson\'s role as a civil-rights pioneer obviously transcends his abilities on the field, he was an excellent ballplayer by any measure, a great contact hitter with some power and consistently great on-base percentages and by all accounts a good defender everywhere he played.Best season: Robinson won the NL MVP award in 1949 when he led the league in batting average and stolen bases. But he stood as one of the game\'s top players from 1949-1952, finishing in the Majors\' top 3 in Wins Above Replacement for four straight seasons.Career Wins Above Replacement: 61.4, despite not entering the big leagues until he was 28 years old.Awards and accolades: Robinson won the first-ever national Rookie of the Year award in 1947, and the prize has since been named in his honor. He won the NL MVP in 1949 and was an All-Star every season from 1949-1954. He was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1962.Fun fact: Though the number of times players were caught stealing was not officially tracked until 1951, four seasons after Robinson entered the league, Robinson stole bases at a great clip into his mid-30s. At age 34 in 1953, he led the Majors with a 80.95% stolen-base percentage.Pee Wee Reese: In the film, the popular Dodgers captain and Kentucky native contributed to Robinson\'s acceptance in the majors by putting his arm around his teammate in front of a harsh Cincinnati crowd \xe2\x80\x93 a moment enshrined in baseball legend and in a statue outside Brooklyn\'s MCU Park. Though Robinson and Reese became lifelong friends, the veracity of the specific gesture depicted in Cincinnati in 1947 has been questioned. In terms of on-field ability, Reese is the only player in 42 whose resume can match Robinson\'s. A great defensive shortstop, "The Little Colonel" racked up 2,170 hits over a 16-season career protracted by service in World War II.Best season: Reese was a steady performer throughout his career peak, but his 1947 stands out for his league-leading 104 walks and his career-high .414 on-base percentage.Career Wins Above Replacement: 66.2Awards and accolades: Reese made the All-Star team in 1942 then, after returning from service, every season from 1946-1954. He won the Lou Gehrig Memorial Award for on- and off-field character in 1956, and was elected to the Hall of Fame by the Veterans\' Committee in 1984.Fun fact: Reese started as a minor leaguer for the Red Sox, but was traded to the Dodgers in 1939 due in part to negative scouting reports from then-Red Sox shortstop/manager Joe Cronin.Hamish Linklater as Ralph Branca and Chadwick Boseman as Jackie Robinson in 42. (PHOTO: Warner Bros.)Ralph Branca: The movie shows Branca as one of the few Dodgers supportive of Robinson from the start, but Branca is perhaps best known as the pitcher who served up Bobby Thomson\'s "Shot Heard \'Round the World" home run to give the Giants the National League pennant over the Dodgers in 1951. Branca was only 21 years old when he lined up next to Robinson on opening day in 1947 but had spent parts of the prior three seasons in the Majors with the Dodgers.Best season: Branca was the Dodgers\' best pitcher in 1947, going 21-12 with a 2.67 ERA over 280 innings and earning his first All-Star nod.Career Wins Above Replacement: 16.3Awards and accolades: Branca made National League All-Star teams in 1947, 1948 and 1949.Fun fact: Branca, who lives in Rye, N.Y., is the only surviving member of the 1947 Dodgers. Though raised Catholic, in 2011 Branca learned from a New York Times reporter that his mother was Jewish, a fact she kept secret while raising him and his 16 siblings to be tolerant of all races and religions.Eddie Stanky: The blond-haired, blue-eyed movie version of Stanky steals a scene in 42 when he confronts opposing Philadelphia\'s explicit, racist manager, Ben Chapman \xe2\x80\x93 his former teammate. Stanky, whose presence at second base for the Dodgers forced Robinson to learn first, was perhaps the most patient hitter of his era. In a time before on-base percentage was widely appreciated as valuable, Stanky led the league in walks in 1945, 1946 and 1950, and \xe2\x80\x93 not surprisingly \xe2\x80\x93 finished among the league leaders in runs scored in all of those seasons.Best season: Reunited with former Brooklyn manager Leo Durocher on the New York Giants in 1950, Durocher posted a career-best .460 on-base percentage and finished third in MVP balloting.Career Wins Above Replacement: 39.3.Awards and accolades: Stanky made All-Star teams in 1947, 1948 and 1950.Fun fact: Durocher loved Stanky. In singing Stanky\'s praises, Durocher said, "nice guys finish last" -- a quote used both in the film and as the title of Durocher\'s autobiography.Branch Rickey and Jackie Robinson in 1949. (PHOTO: Dan Gunther/Getty Images Archive)Branch Rickey: The film gives credit to Rickey, appropriately, for signing Robinson and helping to end baseball\'s tradition of segregation. Not shown (and less important, obviously): 1947 also marked the first year Rickey employed a statistical analyst, and decades before the events depicted in Moneyball, Rickey sung the praises of players who got on base. The 1947 Dodgers, with patient hitters like Robinson, Reese and Stanky, led the Majors in on-base percentage by a wide margin.Best season: Rickey served as a decent catcher for the St. Louis Browns in 1906, but his work as a player and later as a manager pales in comparison to his years as a pioneering executive. So it\'s 1947, the pennant-winning and revolutionary season depicted in the movie.Career Wins Above Replacement: Not really applicable, but 1.1.Awards and accolades: Rickey was elected into the Hall of Fame by the Veterans Committee in 1967.Fun fact: New York-based sportswriter Tom Meany nicknamed Rickey "The Mahatma" after reading a description of Mohandas Ghandi that called the leader of the Indian independence movement "an incredible combination of Jesus Christ, Tammany Hall and your father." But New York Daily News sportswriter Jimmy Powers called Rickey "El Cheapo."Bobby Bragan: Bragan\'s role as an initially hesitant but ultimately accepting Dodger gets his character screen time in 42 that belies the 36 total at-bats he got for Brooklyn in 1947. After only a handful of appearances in 1948, Bragan was released in favor of African-American catcher and future Hall of Famer Ralph Campanella and accepted a job managing the Dodgers\' minor league team in Fort Worth. He went on to a long career as a minor league manager and executive.Best season: Bragan never hit much, but he served as the Phillies\' everyday shortstop and had his best offensive season as a 23-year-old in 1941.Career Wins Above Replacement: 0.9Awards and accolades: Bragan was inducted into state sports Hall of Fames in his native Alabama and in Texas, where he worked for the bulk of his minor league career.Fun fact: Bragan came out of retirement in 2005 to manage the independent Fort Worth Cats for one game and become, at 87, the oldest manager in professional baseball history. He was ejected in the third inning for arguing with an umpire.FacebookTwitterGoogle+LinkedInJackie Robinson Day around MLB\xc2\xa0FullscreenPost to FacebookPosted!A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. [('Series Preview: Baltimore Orioles vs. Tampa Bay Rays, 16 ...', ' Returning to Camden Yards for what will feel like the first "real" homestand of the year, the Orioles sit at .500 after an up-and-down six-game road trip. They start off with a series against the Rays, who currently sit at the bottom of the AL East. With the O\'s seemingly at a disadvantage in each pitching matchup, can their starters surprise and the offense rebound from Sunday\'s shutout? Tuesday, 16 April: Jake Arrieta vs. Roberto Hernandez    Career Numbers Arrieta vs. Rays Hernandez vs. O\'s   IP 33.2 84.0   ERA 5.88 3.64   FIP 5.29 4.52   Slash Line (Past Teams) .234/.333/.419 .280/.347/.441   Slash Line (Current Players) .281/.373/.469 .272/.312/.417     The Orioles managed to beat Hernandez last time they met, but that wasn\'t with Arrieta pitching for them. Arrieta has struggled with command and therefore efficiency in both of his starts this year, lasting only five innings in each. Perhaps he\'ll take a step forward today and save the bullpen an inning or two, but if not, at least the offense may pick up the slack. Hernandez hasn\'t been great this year, either, allowing ten runs (nine earned) in 13.1 IP, so look for the bats to decide this game. Maybe hot: Chris Davis (1.198 OPS, 14 PA); Matt Joyce (1.217 OPS, 15 PA), Yunel Escobar (1.063 PA, 17 PA)    Likely not: Nick Markakis (.591 OPS, 26 PA) Wednesday, 17 April: Chris Tillman vs. Matt Moore    Career Numbers Tillman vs. Rays Moore vs. O\'s   IP 37.2 21.0   ERA 4.78 2.57   FIP 6.36 4.71   Slash Line (Past Teams) .243/.329/.529 .279/.374/.430   Slash Line (Current Players) .257/.366/.586 .321/.406/.500        If you put any stock in small pitcher-vs.-team sample sizes, this looks to be a another slugfest. Tillman has allowed nine home runs and 17 walks in 37.2 innings against the Rays, while Moore has allowed three homers and 13 walks in his 21 innings. Of course, Moore has allowed three hits and zero runs this year, while Tillman\'s given up seven runs in nine innings across two starts. Moore did stuggle with his control last time out, walking six Rangers, so there\'s some reason to hope there, but like Arrieta, Tillman needs to get more pitch-efficient to avoid overworking the O\'s bullpen. Maybe hot: Matt Wieters (2.102 OPS, 2 HR in 11 PA); Evan Longoria (1.850 OPS, 3 HR in 15 PA)    Thursday, 18 April: Miguel Gonzalez vs. David Price    Career Numbers Gonzalez vs. Rays Price vs. O\'s   IP 28.1 87.1   ERA 3.49 2.27   FIP 4.90 2.69   Slash Line (Past Teams) .220/.339/.330 .214/.268/.300   Slash Line (Current Players) .200/.304/.313 .230/.276/.326     Didn\'t we just leave this party? Yes, the O\'s get to face David Price again. At least we won\'t have to hear about how no Oriole has homered off of him this time, since Matt Wieters did on 2 April--apparently Reynolds\'s two HR in one game in 2011 didn\'t count. Gonzalez did pretty well against the Rays last time out (6.1 IP, 2 R, 5 H, 2 BB, 4 K), but struggled with control in his last start in New York. He\'ll need to regain that to give the O\'s a shot at winning this one. Maybe hot: Matt Wieters (.892 OPS, 32 PA) Likely not: Nolan Reimold (.351 OPS, 24 PA) Weaver\'s Third Law: The easiest way around the bases is with one swing of the bat.  ', 'www.camdenchat.com'), ('Orioles react to Boston Marathon tragedy - Page 2 ...', '/* Javascript deferred */var addthis_options = "digg, twitter, facebook, stumbleupon, delicious, friendfeed, buzz, slashdot, reddit, mixx, fark, linkedin, aim, google, myspace, newsvine, technorati, tumblr, typepad, wordpress, more";var addthis_exclude = "print";var addthis_pub     = "archivedigger";/* Javascript deferred */(Page 2 of 2)Orioles react to the Boston Marathon tragedyORIOLES NOTESApril 16, 2013|By Dan Connolly | The Baltimore SunThe Orioles held a moment of silence before Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s game for the victims of the Boston marathon bombing. Also honored by the club during the moment of silence were two Orioles fans who died earlier this year, Tommy Conelius and Matt Hersl. ... All members of the Orioles and Tampa Bay Rays wore No. 42 on Tuesday in honor of baseball pioneer Jackie Robinson. Major League Baseball held its annual tribute to Robinson, who broke the sport\xe2\x80\x99s color barrier in 1947, on Monday, but the Orioles were off. The signed, game-worn jerseys will be auctioned off at www.orioles.com through April 23 with proceeds going to the club\xe2\x80\x99s charitable foundation and the Jackie Robinson Foundation. A \xe2\x80\x9c42\xe2\x80\x9d jersey signed by the team also will be auctioned at www.mlb.com/42 jersey. ... Pitching prospect Kevin Gausman allowed six runs (five earned) in Double-A Bowie\xe2\x80\x99s loss to Erie on Tuesday. Gausman gave up 10 hits, walked none and struck out five in the no decision. He also threw two wild pitches, hit a batter and committed an error. ... Catcher Allan de San Miguel was moved from Short-A Aberdeen\xe2\x80\x99s roster to High-A Frederick to take the place of Michael Ohlman, who was put on the 7-day disabled list with a shoulder injury.dan.connolly@baltsun.comtwitter.com/danconnollysunBaltimore Sun reporter Peter Schmuck contributed to this article. var adSkipCounter = 0; Prev | 1 | 2     window._taboola = window._taboola || [];   _taboola.push({     mode: \'thumbnails-f\',     container: \'taboola-below-article-thumbnails---archives\',     placement: \'Below Article Thumbnails - Archives\',     target_type: \'mix\'   });  MORE:Arundel\'s Hibbs loses scholarship to Florida State after drug arrestHow a prominent black cemetery diedHow the city\'s nickname came to beAre you setting S.M.A.R.T. goals?Trying to clarify convection settingsThe old oyster R-month rule ', 'articles.baltimoresun.com')]

[('Orioles 2, Rays 6: Crapfest? Crapfest. - Camden Chat', " The Orioles played a pretty lousy game tonight. They didn't hit, they didn't pitch, they didn't field. Sometimes you can get away with not doing one of those things, every now and then you can get away with not doing two of those things. But generally if you do none of them, you're gonna lose. So, what went right tonight? Well...Adam Jones hit his second homer of the year. The Orioles took five walks. Tommy Hunter didn't look too bad. That's a pretty short and uninspiring list, but there you go. Now onto the bad. Chris Tillman was a big old mess. He only walked two but he threw so many pitches and went to a three-ball count on too many hitters. He got knocked around for four runs in five innings and gave up two home runs, one each in the first two innings. He threw 93 pitches in five innings and continued the trend of O's starters not going deep in the game. Tillman was replaced by T.J. McFarland, and for those of you calling for him to replace either Tillman or Jake Arrieta in the lineup, tonight wasn't a very good audition. He pitched 2 1/3 innings in relief and gave up two more runs to the Rays.    You won't see it in the boxscore, because it somehow got ruled a double, but Adam Jones made an awful play in center field that allowed two runs to score. On a shallow fly ball to center by James Loney, Jones made the bad decision to try and catch a ball that he wasn't nearly close enough on. When he couldn't make the catch he tried to play it on a bounce but he was too close and it went past him. If he had played it as a single then one run would have scored anyway, but it was really ugly. As I said before, the Orioles did draw five walks on the night, three of which were off of starter Matt Moore, who also gave up five hits. Still, the O's only scored on the homer by Jones, thanks in part to seven strikeouts against Moore. They couldn't do much against the Rays bullpen, getting one hit and two walks over the final 2 1/3 innings. Tomorrow the Orioles have yet another rubber game and turn to Miguel Gonzalez to right the ship. Of course, the bats will also need to wake up, and with David Price on the mound that's a pretty tall order.     ", 'www.camdenchat.com')]

It was Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s 17th straight extra-inning victory, including 16 last season.Nolan Reimold and Steve Pearce also homered for the Orioles, who took two of three games from the Rays.Desmond Jennings, Evan Longoria, Jose Molina and James Loney each hit a solo home run for Tampa Bay.RED SOX 6, INDIANS 3 Jon Lester pitched seven strong innings as visiting Boston beat Cleveland for its sixth straight win.Indians Manager Terry Francona, who managed Boston for eight seasons and led the Red Sox to World Series titles in 2004 and 2007, was swept in the first series against his former team.
