Police say Richard Nicolas killed 2-year-old Aja, but friends say they\'re certain he didn\'t. ', 'articles.baltimoresun.com')]

[('At 20, Manny Machado has stardom, wife in near future', 'The Orioles\' Manny Machado, right, is friends with the Padres\' Yonder Alonso, left, and is engaged to Alonso\'s sister, Yainee.(Photo: Joy R. Absalon, Special for USA TODAY Sports)Story HighlightsManny Machado and Yonder Alonso are best friends and rising starsAlonso\'s sister, 23-year-old Yainee, is Machado\'s fianc\xc3\xa9eMachado has been somewhat overlooked on the national landscapeCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREBALTIMORE -- Manny Machado, with his fianc\xc3\xa9e sitting to his left, his best friend to his right and his 4-month-old puppy on the floor, crinkles his nose and narrows his dark brown eyes.By one measure, no player in the American League means more to his team this year than Machado. Yet at the moment, this 20-year-old Baltimore Orioles sensation can barely squeeze in two sentences.Not when San Diego Padres first baseman Yonder Alonso, his best friend, is singing his praises.Tuesday night, Alonso and Machado, who hail from the baseball hotbed of South Florida, met on a major league diamond for the first time when the Padres and Orioles played an interleague game at Camden Yards.When Machado singled in his first at-bat and greeted Alonso, 26, their interaction differed from the usual in-game fraternization.Alonso is not just a friend but about to become family.Alonso\'s sister, 23-year-old Yainee,  is Machado\'s fianc\xc3\xa9e. The wedding is set for Dec. 6, 2014, in Paris.And Yonder is not waiting until the nuptials to speak his mind.So much of the airwaves and digital universe have been dominated by the game\'s fair-haired youngsters, Mike Trout of the Los Angeles Angels and Bryce Harper of the Washington Nationals, that Machado has been somewhat overlooked on the national landscape.And, oh, how Yonder has noticed."It\'s wrong; it\'s just wrong," he says. "I hate that. It\'s not right. You\'re not going to compare him to Trout and the other dude? That sucks."Look at the numbers; Manny is better. He\'s putting up better numbers. He\'s nicer. He\'s more likable. Everything. That\'s the reality of it."I know he\'s going to let his game talk, but he\'s better than both guys. I think the other guys will have great careers, but when you talk about the best young players in the game, why can\'t you involve Manny in it?"Consider it done.Despite starting nearly four months after Trout and Harper, Machado proves he belongs in the conversation. He hit .294 with 12 homers and 50 RBI in his first 89 games, eclipsing Harper\'s production in a similar span and tying Trout in homers.This year, Machado, like Trout and Harper, has transcended wunderkind status and become a legitimate star. Machado was batting .331 with 28 runs and 24 RBI entering Tuesday, and in the previous 19 games he hit .405 with 12 multiple-hit games, including three doubles, one triple, three homers and 13 RBI.Machado entered Tuesday with three consecutive three-hit games. The only Orioles players with longer streaks are Cal Ripken Jr., Eddie Murray and Don Buford.All this, while evoking Charm City memories of Hall of Fame third baseman Brooks Robinson."And you tell me he\'s not as good as those two other guys?" says Yonder, who was batting .275 with four homers and 23 RBI entering Tuesday. "Come on."Machado just grins. He might be two months shy of legal drinking age, but he\'s mature enough to know not to join this debate."I just go about my business, put up numbers and do my thing," Machado says. "Just go out there, have fun, and everything else will fall in place."One day, perhaps after the 2014 season when J.J. Hardy\'s contract expires, Machado will be back at shortstop, like Ripken and Alex Rodriguez in reverse. He already leads American League position players in WAR, which rates the total value of a player, and various defensive metrics rate him the best defensive third baseman in baseball.He\'d love to show he can become the game\'s best shortstop, too."You think about it, it\'s in the back of your mind," says Machado, who ranks his meeting with Robinson this season as the highlight of his career. "But I love this game so much, I just want to be out there. If you stop having fun, that\'s when you struggle."Says Yonder, "He has so much God-given ability, I don\'t think he\'ll ever struggle like the rest of us."***No place like homeMachado, considered the Orioles\' most exciting young player to come along since Ripken debuted in 1981, walks with Yainee into their neighborhood Starbucks.He orders the usual, white chocolate mocha. Yainee does the same, only hot.The woman behind the counter recognizes Machado and hand-delivers the drink to him without charge, saying, "Here you go, honey."Yainee has to pay."I\'m right there, but, hey, I don\'t play baseball," Yainee says, laughing.Yainee, once a member of the Miami Marlins\' Mermaids cheerleading squad,  graduated from Miami (Fla.) in December in pre-med. She is taking classes to be a physician\'s assistant. These days, her life is filled with baseball, living with Machado in an upscale condo  10 minutes from Baltimore\'s Inner Harbor and keeping track of her brother in San Diego."I always tell (Machado) he\'s lucky," Yainee says. "I know baseball. I know what to say, and what not to say, at the right times."I learned that from my brother."No one will ask them to make a reality show, they say.  They don\'t go to clubs. Well, they can\'t anyway, since Machado doesn\'t turn 21 until July 6. They sit home and watch TV, addicted to Swamp People and The Walking Dead.They\'ll play Call of Duty when Machado isn\'t engaging Yonder in NBA or FIFA battles.The only time they really disagree on anything is when watching the NBA. Machado is a die-hard Miami Heat fan. The Alonsos are life-long Los Angeles Lakers fans."It\'s a house divided," Yainee says. "We don\'t want to get on that subject."Says Machado, "I\'ve always been a huge LeBron (James) fan."So imagine Machado\'s reaction when they got their new dog in spring training, an Alaskan Klee Kai, and Yainee got to name him.Kobe."Come on, Kobe sounds better than LeBron," Yonder says. "What kind of name is that for a dog? My sister is loyal."This is what made it a bit awkward when Yonder\'s close friendship with Machado suddenly took on a third member, which evolved into a wedding engagement three months ago.\xc2\xa0(Photo: Gary A. Vasquez, USA TODAY Sports)***Friends and family"He would come over to the house every single day," Yonder says, "and we\'d just hang out and play video games."Then, it was like, \'Hey, man, you\'re not coming over to the house every day just to see me, man. What is the deal here, dude?\'"The three of them went on vacation to Spain in the winter of 2011, and when they returned, Machado knew he wanted to be more than friends with Yainee. He nervously asked Yonder if it was OK to date his sister."I told him, \'Look, as long as you respect her and be there for her,\'" Yonder says. "And whatever happens, just know if something happens between you guys we\'re still friends. We were friends before, and we\'ll be friends afterward."The dating morphed into love, and Machado drove Yainee to South Beach on Feb. 6 to propose. It wasn\'t something quite out of Hollywood. The kitchen sink broke during the day. The Cuban dinner was postponed until late evening. There was a homeless man sleeping on the beach right where Machado was about to propose."I was a mess," Machado says. "I was struggling to get the ring out. It was stuck in my pocket."Says Yainee: "He\'s on his knees and talking, saying sweet things, and I didn\'t even hear him propose. Guys think that it\'s like the movies, the woman says yes automatically. But you are so in shock. I finally said yes, but then I asked him to ask me again, because I didn\'t hear him."Now they\'re about to become family, with Yonder staying at Machado\'s condo instead of the Padres\' team hotel while in town. One active player is known to be married to a major league colleague\'s sister; Minnesota Twins pitcher Josh Roenicke is married to Nikki Desmond, sister of Washington Nationals shortstop Ian.The Machado-Alonso ties date to 2009, when Yonder, then a junior at Miami, introduced himself by phone. Yonder, whose family defected from Cuba in 1995, said his agent wanted to see if he could recruit him. He declined the role but told Machado, who grew up in a single-family home, that if he ever needed anything or wanted to work out with him and his buddies to please call."I said to myself, \'If he really wants to work and be really good, he\'ll call,\'" Yonder says. "A year goes by, and then he starts texting and calling me all of the time."When he gets drafted (third overall in 2010, behind Harper and Jameson Taillon of the Pittsburgh Pirates), he then signs, he says, \'I\'m ready. I want to train and do the things I need to do.\'"***No shortcutsMachado didn\'t even know how to perform squats in the weight room  but soon became Yonder\'s shadow during intense winter workouts. To this day, they talk by phone every morning, dissecting the previous night\'s games, their hitting strokes, opposing pitchers and strategy.Yes, every once in a while, Yainee joins the conversation.It\'s this workout regimen that has Machado and Yonder seething at the hits their hometown took in baseball\'s most recent doping scandal.It\'s as if every player from Miami who performs well, they say, must be on performance-enhancing drugs, thanks to the Biogenesis Clinic scandal and the reports that Rodriguez, their boyhood idol, was at the center of the illegal drug use."It\'s obviously unfortunate and not something anyone wants to hear about," says Alonso, whose Padres and Miami teammate Yasmani Grandal is serving a 50-game suspension for a positive testosterone test and was tied to the Biogenesis scandal. "But to us, this situation shouldn\'t be so negative. People are taking this so wrong. I think there\'s a lot of positive things we can learn from and understand from it."What we\'ve learned is that those things are unacceptable in this game and will never be accepted. The sport is extremely clean, and it\'s getting better all of the time."People don\'t realize all of the sacrifices we go through. Yes, there are a few guys who did things wrong, but there are thousands of people playing in Miami who do it right. They don\'t see us coming in every day at 8 a.m., busting our ass and working as hard as we can. Those are the things that really piss us off."Says Machado: "People want to judge you because where you\'re from. That\'s not right."Yonder and Machado might live in Miami but say they never heard of Biogenesis until the Miami New Times\' report on the clinic, which has since closed.They eschew South Beach\'s legendary nightlife. They  don\'t wear tropical shirts open with diamond-encrusted chains dangling from their necks."People think, "Oh, you\'re a big-leaguer, you live in Miami, you can probably go to any club you want," Machado says. "The truth is that we are boring. We don\'t really let people in. We\'ve got a very close circle, and that\'s it."For us, it\'s all about family."It\'s why Machado, who bought his mom, Rosa Nunez, a home with his $5.4 million signing bonus, flew her to Minnesota last weekend so they could spend Mother\'s Day together, while Yonder and Yainee were in Tampa with their parents, Luis, an executive with Sherwin-Williams, and Damaris, an accountant."I grew up without a father in my life," says Machado, who has infrequent contact with him now, "and I see how Yonder and Yainee grew up with their family. I want that. I\'ve always wanted that."Family means everything to me, and now I can say we are all family."CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE ', 'www.usatoday.com'), ('Orioles Lose To Padres 3-2 On Jim Johnson\\u2019s Blown Save ...', ' BALTIMORE (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 When closer Jim Johnson walks to the mound in the ninth inning with the Baltimore Orioles ahead, the outcome is all but decided. For 35 straight games, Johnson came through in save situations. On the 36th such occasion, the right-hander finally gave a lead away. Chris Denorfia and Everth Cabrera hit two-out RBI singles off Johnson in the ninth, and the San Diego Padres got a home run from Carlos Quentin in a 3-2 victory Tuesday night. After the Orioles took a 2-1 lead in the eighth, Johnson (1-3) entered to try and secure the win. He gave up two consecutive singles before getting Jedd Gyorko to hit into a 6-4-3 double play. But Denorfia followed with a single up the middle and, after Johnson hit Nick Hundley with a pitch, Cabrera singled to center for a 3-2 lead. Johnson hadn\xe2\x80\x99t blown a save opportunity since July 27, 2012, against Oakland. His streak of 35 broke the previous team record of 34, set in 1997 by Randy Myers. \xe2\x80\x9cI really didn\xe2\x80\x99t put a whole lot of stock into it,\xe2\x80\x9d the right-hander said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was just something you guys like to talk about.\xe2\x80\x9d He blamed his reversal of fortune on poor location. \xe2\x80\x9cAs soon as I got off the field I looked, and pitches were in different spots than they\xe2\x80\x99re normally at,\xe2\x80\x9d Johnson said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s about execution. At this level the talent is too good. You have to execute and tonight I didn\xe2\x80\x99t and wasted a good effort from a lot of guys on this team.\xe2\x80\x9d His teammates couldn\xe2\x80\x99t remember the last time he blew a save. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was the first time I\xe2\x80\x99d ever seen it happen,\xe2\x80\x9d said second baseman Ryan Flaherty, who played all last season with Baltimore. \xe2\x80\x9cThat was incredible. He comes in the game and it\xe2\x80\x99s 1-2-3, and the game\xe2\x80\x99s over and everyone goes home. So, you get accustomed to that. You got a couple of balls that went through, and that\xe2\x80\x99s going to happen.\xe2\x80\x9d San Diego won after losing three straight in Tampa Bay, despite holding the lead in the fifth inning or later in each game. \xe2\x80\x9cTo get to (Johnson) is a great accomplishment for us,\xe2\x80\x9d Padres manager Bud Black said. \xe2\x80\x9cThose are great on the road, they really are, to snatch one back when they took the lead.\xe2\x80\x9d Cabrera\xe2\x80\x99s hit was the 60,000th in Padres history. Luke Gregerson (2-2) got the last out in the eighth and Huston Street earned his ninth save. The Padres were 0-18 when trailing after eight innings. Street gave up a game-ending homer in the ninth against Tampa Bay on Saturday, so he was determined to make things right. \xe2\x80\x9cThe one in Tampa frustrated me more than any save in my life,\xe2\x80\x9d Street said. \xe2\x80\x9cI took a lot of responsibility for not making those pitches. It bugged me, so tonight was one I really wanted.\xe2\x80\x9d He then said something that Johnson can take to heart. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can come back and get it done,\xe2\x80\x9d Street said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what this game is all about. It\xe2\x80\x99s bouncing back. It\xe2\x80\x99s just moving on to the next day and making the next pitch. You make the next pitch and good things will happen.\xe2\x80\x9d Flaherty homered for the Orioles, who fell to 18-2 when leading after eight. With the score tied at 1 in the eighth, Flaherty drew a one-out walk from Andrew Cashner and was replaced by pinch-runner Alexi Casilla. After Cashner threw to first base several times to check the runner, Casilla took off for second. The throw from Hundley came up short and bounced into the outfield, allowing Casilla to reach third on the error. Steve Pearce followed with a line-drive single to left to chase Cashner, who matched a career high by working 7 1-3 innings. Orioles starter Chris Tillman allowed one run, four hits and two walks in seven innings. Although the right-hander wasn\xe2\x80\x99t involved in the decision, he lowered his ERA to 3.40 and remained unbeaten since April 17. It was the first meeting between the teams since 2010 and first in Baltimore since 2002. The series is tied at 5. Quentin led off the second inning with a drive to left to put the Padres up 1-0. San Diego then loaded the bases with two outs before Tillman struck out Cabrera. Flaherty tied it in the third with an opposite-field fly that dropped into the front row of the left-field seats. It was only the second home run off Cashner in his five starts this season. In the sixth, Quentin\xe2\x80\x99s bid for another home run was denied by center fielder Adam Jones, who made a leaping catch at the top of the 7-foot wall. NOTES: The Orioles placed LHP Wei-Yin Chen (strained right oblique) on the 15-day disabled list and recalled RHP Alex Burnett and INF Yamaico Navarro from Triple-A Norfolk. \xe2\x80\xa6 The Padres have hit 20 homers in their last 15 games. \xe2\x80\xa6 Orioles LHP Tsuyoshi Wada, recovering from elbow ligament replacement surgery, will make his first rehabilitation start Thursday for Norfolk. \xe2\x80\xa6 Jason Marquis (4-2) starts for the Padres against Freddy Garcia (0-1) in the series finale Wednesday afternoon. \xe2\x80\xa6 Of the 47 home runs Tillman has allowed in his career, 32 have been solo shots. (Copyright 2013 by The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.)  var addthis_product = \'wpp-261\'; var addthis_config = {"data_track_clickback":true};if (typeof(addthis_share) == "undefined"){ addthis_share = {"url_transforms":{"shorten":{"twitter":"bitly"}},"shorteners":{"bitly":{"login":"cbslocal","apiKey":"R_bfe2742f79bb4091b0fcfbdf5c6a81ca"}}};}  ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com')]

[('Orioles Manager Buck Showalter Talks Baltimore Baseball ...', ' Baltimore Orioles Manager Buck Showalter joined the Norris & Davis show to talk about his team.\xc2\xa0 The Orioles are currently in 2nd place in the AL East with 23-16 record. They will finish up their series against the San Diego Padres today. (Photo by J. Meric/Getty Images) Steve asked about Jim Johnson and if he saw anything different. Buck said no that there has been nights where Jim didn\xe2\x80\x99t have his best stuff and went 1, 2, 3. Bob asked about Chris Tillman\xe2\x80\x99s outing. Buck said that Chris looks to be growing into a lot of thing. He told the guys that Tillman gave up 24 foul balls in the first four innings and that is the difference between Triple A and Major League Baseball. Steve wanted know about Manny Machado\xe2\x80\x99s comparison to Jeter. Buck said that he would never put that kind of pressure on Manny.\xc2\xa0 What he has seen is the support system that Manny has from family and teammates.\xc2\xa0 Buck said you can tell that Manny loves baseball and is very alert to his surroundings. Bob asked about Freddy Garcia\xe2\x80\x99s transition from power pitcher to finesse pitcher. Buck said that today will be a tough game to pitch but Freddy will keep giving the team a chance to win.  Orioles Manager Buck Showalter ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com'), ('Five Baltimore Orioles statistics that stand out this week ...', '/* Javascript deferred */var addthis_options = "digg, twitter, facebook, stumbleupon, delicious, friendfeed, buzz, slashdot, reddit, mixx, fark, linkedin, aim, google, myspace, newsvine, technorati, tumblr, typepad, wordpress, more";var addthis_exclude = "print";var addthis_pub     = "archivedigger";/* Javascript deferred */Five Baltimore Orioles stats that stand out this weekMay 15, 2013|By Matt Vensel | The Baltimore SunEach Wednesday, blogger Matt Vensel will highlight five statistics that really mean something for the Orioles.five -- consecutive quality starts for Chris Tillman.Right-hander Chris Tillman pitched seven strong innings Tuesday night, allowing four hits and one earned run to give the Orioles his fifth straight quality start (closer Jim Johnson could not secure the win for him, though). Over Tillman\'s past five starts, he has a 1.87 ERA and opponents are batting .195 against him. He recorded three wins and the Orioles won four of those five games. In his eight starts, Tillman leads all Orioles starters with 47 2/3 innings pitched and his five quality starts are tied with Wei-Yin Chen for the team lead.11 -- errors committed by the Orioles in 39 games.The Orioles lost to the San Diego Padres on Tuesday night, but it was another error-free night at the ballpark for Orioles defenders. With 11 errors in 39 games, the Orioles are first in the American League and second in the major league to only the Arizona Diamondbacks, who have committed 10. Their .992 fielding percentage is second in baseball, too. According to MASN, the Orioles have been especially mistake-free of late, committing just two errors in their past 17 games and four in their past 24. var adSkipCounter = 0; .400 -- Steve Pearce\xe2\x80\x99s average in his past 25 at-bats.Steve Pearce recorded 15 straight outs to start the 2013 season, a hitless streak he snapped with a home run in a win over the Tampa Bay Rays on April 18. Starting with that hit, Pearce, who is usually used as a designated hitter, has since gone 10-for-25 with two home runs and seven RBIs. By batting .400 over that nine-game stretch, he has increased his season average from a string of goose eggs to a respectable .250.nine -- hits for Manny Machado this past weekend.Third baseman Manny Machado had three hits in each game of the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 three-game series against the Minnesota Twins over the weekend. According to the Elias Sports Bureau, Machado was the first player younger than 21 to have three or more hits in three straight games since a Pittsburgh Pirates rookie named Rennie Stennett did it in September 1971. Machado\'s average spiked from .306 to .331, though it has dipped slightly to .329 after he had just one hit -- slacker! -- in Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s loss to the Padres.3.09 -- flight time of Adam Jones\xe2\x80\x99 homer on Sunday.Center fielder Adam Jones also had a strong series in Minnesota, including a solo home run in Sunday\'s 6-0 win. According to ESPN Stats and Info, his third-inning home run off of Twins starter Scott Diamond had a flight time of 3.09 seconds, the quickest of any home run this season. It was also the quickest home run ever hit at Target Field. This isn\xe2\x80\x99t really a useful stat, but it\xe2\x80\x99s pretty interesting.Bloggers note: Have a nifty stat you want to share? E-mail me at matt.vensel@baltsun.com or contact me on Twitter at @mattvensel. If I end up using it, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be sure to give you a nice plug on the blog.     window._taboola = window._taboola || [];   _taboola.push({     mode: \'thumbnails-f\',     container: \'taboola-below-article-thumbnails---archives\',     placement: \'Below Article Thumbnails - Archives\',     target_type: \'mix\'   });  MORE:Whether a stent is needed can be tough callWhy expansion tank is needed\'Blushing\' ear is no cause for alarm7 Ways Michael Jackson Changed The WorldCivil War wasn\'t to end slavery Purposes: The South fought to defend slavery. The North\'s focus was not to end slavery but to preserve the union. The slavery apology debate misses these facts.A tragic case of contradictions Slaying: A father and daughter\'s first outing alone would be their last. Police say Richard Nicolas killed 2-year-old Aja, but friends say they\'re certain he didn\'t. ', 'articles.baltimoresun.com'), ('5/15: Birds Watcher- Orioles drop a tough pitchers\\u2019 duel', 'If you\xe2\x80\x99re a fan of pitching, last night\xe2\x80\x99s Baltimore Orioles game against San Diego was for you. Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 starter Chris Tillman had his struggles, and in fact he got off to an inauspicious start when Carlos Quentin bashed a solo home run in the second inning. Tillman also had a few guys on base here and there, and got himself into a few jams. However as I\xe2\x80\x99ve said previously, pitchers are going to get themselves into trouble over time; it\xe2\x80\x99s the nature of the position for the most part. It\xe2\x80\x99s how you deal with the guys on base or \xe2\x80\x9cthe jams\xe2\x80\x9d which separates the men from the boys.Courtesy of Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY SportsIf we\xe2\x80\x99re talking about runs surrendered, Tillman dealt with the \xe2\x80\x9ctrouble\xe2\x80\x9d very well. The aforementioned home run was the only run he gave up. Tillman\xe2\x80\x99s line: 7 IP, 4 H, 1 R, 2 BB, 7 K. That\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty decent stat line from the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 standpoint. However the one area where Tillman did struggle just a bit was the same aspect in which Oriole starters have struggled all year: pitch count. Part of that has to do with the seven strikeouts, as that costs a\xc2\xa0bare minimum\xc2\xa0of 21 pitches right there. After four innings Tillman had thrown 92 pitches, but he finished with 112 total pitches in the game (over his final three innings he only threw 20 pitches total). Tillman seemed to step it up a notch in the sixth inning when Carlos Quentin made another home run bid (or at the very least a bid for extra bases) by sending a shot to center field. However Adam Jones chased the ball down and made a leaping catch at the wall, awarding Quentin nothing more than a loud out for his trouble.The Orioles tied the score at one in the third inning when Ryan Flaherty sent an opposite-field home run into the left field grandstand. For the record, San Diego starter Andrew Cashner was as solid as Tillman was. I think that there are probably a lot of Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 fans out there this morning who are complaining about the team\xe2\x80\x99s offensive production last night, and perhaps justifiably so in many aspects. However this was an old fashioned pitchers\xe2\x80\x99 duel. Guys not getting on base is what happens in these kinds of games. San Diego manager Bud Black probably left Cashner in just a bit too long, as he started to elevate his pitches in the last of the eighth. Ryan Flaherty drew a walk, and was lifted for pinch runner Alexi Casilla\xe2\x80\xa6who promptly stole second and then went to third on an E2. Steve Pearce\xe2\x80\x98s RBI-single scored Casilla, and the O\xe2\x80\x99s suddenly led this game late by the score of 2-1.So with the Orioles taking the lead in the last of the eighth, that meant the top of the ninth was Jim Johnson time. Johnson of course held a team record of 35 consecutive saves converted (and counting). Good morning, good afternoon, and good night, right? Generally speaking, yes. San Diego had two outs and a runner on third, and Chris Denorfia sent a single up the middle which scored the runner from third and tied the game. That goes as a blown save for Johnson, ending his consecutive games saved streak. Nick Hundley was hit by a pitch, which put Denorfia in scoring position, and Everth Cabrera\xe2\x80\x98s RBI-single scored Denorfia. Suddenly the Birds trailed, and while they got the tying run on base in the last of the ninth they were unable to bring it across home plate.The issue at hand is not Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s consecutive games saved streak, but moreso the fact that this was a game that the Orioles would rather not have dropped. However the fact is that a baseball season comes with 60 wins and 60 losses all but guaranteed. Included in those 60 losses will be games like this. For the Orioles, it seems that the shoe is almost always on the other foot in these kinds of games, especially at home. Furthermore with regard to Johnson, as Buck Showalter always says,\xc2\xa0we\xe2\x80\x99re dealing with human beings here.\xc2\xa0Nobody feels worse about that than Johnson, but even he knew that at some point he\xe2\x80\x99d blow a save. As I said above, pitchers will eventually get themselves in trouble. Jim Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s no exception to that.It\xe2\x80\x99s also easy to say that the Orioles would have won this game had they gotten more people on base, scored more runs, etc. That goes without saying. However the ebb and flow of the game was that of a pitcher\xe2\x80\x99s duel. Today might well be an offensive shoot out for all we know. part of baseball is taking the good with the bad. Luckily for the Orioles, not only do they get back on the horse today, but they get to do so early. This afternoon\xe2\x80\x99s series finale is a 12:35 \xe2\x80\x9cbusinessman\xe2\x80\x99s special.\xe2\x80\x9d All of Birdland \xe2\x80\x93 I REPEAT \xe2\x80\x93 All of Birdland\xc2\xa0has my expressed and written permission to skip out of work to attend today\xe2\x80\x99s game! That aside, Freddy Garcia will take to the mound for the Birds this afternoon, against a San Diego team of which he was a part during Spring Training. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t make the roster out of camp, and later signed with the O\xe2\x80\x99s. Garcia will be opposed by crafty southpaw Jason Marquis.Incidentally, the Orioles made a few roster moves prior to yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s game. Wei-Yin Chen was sent to the 15-day DL with a strained oblique, and as a corresponding move the O\xe2\x80\x99s recalled Alex Burnett. On Monday the Orioles had also optioned Mike Belfiore back to triple-A Norfolk; yesterday they announced the corresponding move, which was to recall infielder Yamaico Navarro. With the off days being what they are, the O\xe2\x80\x99s won\xe2\x80\x99t need a fifth starter until next week. Burnett will serve as bullpen support and Navarro as bench support in the interim. ', 'birdswatcher.com'), ("Orioles shortstop J.J. Hardy isn't in love with his new ...", '/* Javascript deferred */var addthis_options = "digg, twitter, facebook, stumbleupon, delicious, friendfeed, buzz, slashdot, reddit, mixx, fark, linkedin, aim, google, myspace, newsvine, technorati, tumblr, typepad, wordpress, more";var addthis_exclude = "print";var addthis_pub     = "archivedigger";/* Javascript deferred */Orioles shortstop J.J. Hardy isn\'t in love with his new gloveMay 15, 2013|By Dan Connolly | The Baltimore SunIn a sense, baseball players are a lot like other craftsmen.They have tools they become comfortable with over the years, and it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to make a change when a manufacturer discontinues or alters a product.That\xe2\x80\x99s sort of what has happened to Orioles shortstop J.J. Hardy this season, although it was actually baseball\xe2\x80\x99s umpires who led to a change in Hardy\xe2\x80\x99s most treasured piece of equipment.Since he broke into the majors in 2005, Hardy used a Rawlings Pro 200 4K 11-1/2 inch model glove. It\xe2\x80\x99s made of \xe2\x80\x9ckipskin leather\xe2\x80\x9d and is a cream color. If you Google \xe2\x80\x9cRawlings Pro 200 4K\xe2\x80\x9d you can quickly find the \xe2\x80\x9cJ.J. Hardy Game Day Glove\xe2\x80\x9d for $329.99. var adSkipCounter = 0; There\xe2\x80\x99s just one problem. Hardy can\xe2\x80\x99t really use it in a game. Or at least not now.Apparently last year umpires began complaining that the cream color made it difficult for them to view the ball entering the glove \xe2\x80\x94 affecting calls such as short hops versus catching the ball in the air.\xe2\x80\x9cUmpires didn\xe2\x80\x99t want us using this color anymore because they have a hard time seeing the ball go in because it is kind of the same color as the ball \xe2\x80\x94 but not really,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hardy, who won his first Rawlings Gold Glove Award in 2012.This spring, Rawlings told Hardy they would still make him his version of the glove, but they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t guarantee that umpires would allow him to use it. They told the same thing to infielders, pitchers and outfielders that used the creamed color leather.\xe2\x80\x9cSo it\xe2\x80\x99s not an official rule,\xe2\x80\x9d Hardy said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to push it.\xe2\x80\x9dSo Hardy is now using a Rawlings Pro 200 4RT. It\xe2\x80\x99s supposedly an exact replica, just a rust colored glove. And, yet, Hardy senses that it is different.\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the same glove; same leather, just a different color. And I just don\xe2\x80\x99t like it as much,\xe2\x80\x9d Hardy said. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know why. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know if it is the same. Just like everything else it is a feel thing. You have to feel good and comfortable.\xe2\x80\x9dBaseball players are a superstitious group. So could the \xe2\x80\x9cdifference\xe2\x80\x9d just be in his head?\xe2\x80\x9cIt could be,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a smile. \xe2\x80\x9cBaseball people will tell you gloves are a feel thing. And it just doesn\xe2\x80\x99t feel the same.\xe2\x80\x9dThere could be a silver lining to this off-color story, though. Hardy met with a Rawlings representative in Anaheim earlier this month and was told that Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x99s Chase Utley and St. Louis\xe2\x80\x99 David Freese still use a cream-colored glove.The rep took a picture of Hardy\xe2\x80\x99s, and they sent it to umpiring headquarters for a ruling. A hopeful Hardy has ordered a couple of his old models from the manufacturer, and he hopes to get an answer soon.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m still using the other one. It\xe2\x80\x99s broken in,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all right. But I definitely like the old one better."     window._taboola = window._taboola || [];   _taboola.push({     mode: \'thumbnails-f\',     container: \'taboola-below-article-thumbnails---archives\',     placement: \'Below Article Thumbnails - Archives\',     target_type: \'mix\'   });  MORE:Whether a stent is needed can be tough callWhy expansion tank is needed\'Blushing\' ear is no cause for alarm7 Ways Michael Jackson Changed The WorldCivil War wasn\'t to end slavery Purposes: The South fought to defend slavery. The North\'s focus was not to end slavery but to preserve the union. The slavery apology debate misses these facts.A tragic case of contradictions Slaying: A father and daughter\'s first outing alone would be their last. Police say Richard Nicolas killed 2-year-old Aja, but friends say they\'re certain he didn\'t. ', 'articles.baltimoresun.com')]

[("How Do The Orioles' Hitters Stack Up By Position Against ...", ' Watching the bottom of the Orioles\' lineup, frequently manned by the second baseman and designated hitter of the night, there is the temptation to make sweeping proclamations about how bad they are. One might be tempted, for instance, to give in to the natural human tendency towards hyperbole and say that the Orioles designated hitters and second basemen are, collectively, the worst-hitting of either kind in the American League. In general, it\'s hard to say whether this is even a bad thing, this tendency. In this particular situation, it\'s even harder to say so, because that hyperbole is the truth. The Orioles have the worst-hitting second basemen (measured by OPS) in all of MLB, and the-worst hitting DH in all of the American League. Through 40 games, two of the nine positions in the every day lineup are the worst of their kind. They are not merely bad. Compared to their competitors, they are literally the worst that there is. The DH for the Orioles has been so bad that it is the second-worst of any unit for any team in the AL, bested, or perhaps worsted, by Seattle shortstops, who are mustering a measly .338 OPS. Good God. That almost makes the .488 OPS of Orioles DH look balmy in comparison, except, wait, no it doesn\'t. That\'s awful. I might have to go cry now. Lest we dwell on nothing but the bad, here\'s how the Orioles are faring at each position against their peers. The alchemy of talent and good fortune have the Orioles standing above most or all of the rest in some positions even as their 2B and DH languish at the bottom.        Position AVG OBP SLG OPS Rank (AL)   DH .148 .244 .244 15   C .227 .304 .404 7   1B .321 .417 .664 1   2B .187 .257 .273 15   3B .343 .379 .541 3   SS .227 .259 .396 10   LF .278 .360 .456 2   CF .311 .347 .479 3   RF .307 .350 .416 7      Four positions (1B, 3B, LF, CF) are better than most or all of their peers, with 1B, being mostly Chris Davis, as the best by more than 100 points of OPS over the closest competitor. This is the highest positional OPS in all of MLB. Two (C, RF) are about average, at least if we measure by OPS. One (SS) is below average, and the two mentioned in the introduction are the worst. All of this together adds up to a team slash line of .263/.325/.431, a .756 OPS that ranks fifth in the American League, with the only divisional opponent the Orioles trail being Boston. The AL East teams rank 4th-8th in the AL in overall OPS, with Tampa Bay, New York, and Toronto following immediately after the Orioles. Toronto has a .725 OPS, which is the worst of the division. The best team OPS in the AL is Cleveland, with a .791 OPS through their 39 games.    Frustrating as it is to see those black holes in the lineup every night, the Orioles could be doing a lot worse than they are, and the rest of the lineup is generally doing enough to make up for those players who aren\'t performing. There should be concern if Davis, Manny Machado, and/or Nate McLouth fall back into the pack, which is a possibility, no matter how many "through X games" comparisons to Harper and Trout the local and national media want to make with Machado. If those players stumble, then the bottom of the lineup will really drag down the team more than they already do. Are there any solutions to the big problems here? Second base seems to be mostly stuck where it is. There could be some light at the end of the tunnel for DH, with Steve Pearce heating up - he\'s now out-OPSing the likes of Nick Markakis and Matt Wieters - and the struggling Nolan Reimold relegated to the bench. Anything Pearce can contribute above a .488 OPS is an improvement over what we\'ve seen so far. Pearce\'s current .759 OPS would still only rank 11th among AL teams, but in absolute terms, would be a huge stride. Even shortstop might get better, if you squint. J.J. Hardy is currently working on an 11-game hitting streak, with four home runs in that stretch. Even with that, he\'s still only batting the .227/.259/.396 you see above. He\'s not going to turn into one of the best hitters in the AL, but if he was slumping in April and is now warming up, he could pick up some slack offensively to go along with his already-excellent fielding. They are good enough to get by, if the starting rotation settles into some kind of consistency that isn\'t consistently bad. But that is another subject for another day. For now, take comfort in this: for every Ryan Flaherty, there is a Davis; for every Reimold, there is a Machado. So far, that\'s enough for the Orioles to win.  ', 'www.camdenchat.com')]

[('5/20: Birds Watcher- Orioles: Step Back from the Panic Button', 'Here at the end of a 5-game losing streak, Orioles fans are beginning to wonder if the time has come to hit the panic button. To that I would say, \xe2\x80\x9cMake note of where the button is, but don\xe2\x80\x99t smash it just yet.\xe2\x80\x9dThe past five games have been painful indeed. However, two of them were pitched well enough to have most often been a win (if there was run support), and two of them had sufficient run production to have most often been a win if there was reasonably solid pitching. My guess is that the poor pitching will be more remembered than the games with poor hitting.May 19, 2013; Baltimore, MD, USA; Baltimore Orioles manager Buck Showalter (26) during a game against the Tampa Bay Rays at Oriole Park at Camden Yards. Mandatory Credit: Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY SportsTeams will go through stretches like this during a season \xe2\x80\x93 even the best clubs. The Orioles had a similar streak last year where they lost six consecutive games from May 26 through June 1 \xe2\x80\xa6 two to KC, three to Toronto, and one to Tampa Bay. Great players go through occasional setbacks, and it is inevitable that even a stalwart like Jim Johnson is going to have a rough stretch. Let\xe2\x80\x99s not forget that this is a team that won 109 consecutive games when leading after seven innings \xe2\x80\x93 nearly an unprecedented statistic. Baseball is simply a sport where things even out over time, which is why it takes 162 games to determine who is the best for the playoffs.Without doubt, the starting pitching is the largest concern. Chris Tillman is a solid performer at this juncture. Wei-Yin Chen should not be out that terribly long, and Miguel Gonzalez\xe2\x80\x99 injury is not of the catastrophic sort. Jason Hammel is a larger concern at this time, but he has gone through stints like this in the past and figured out how to make the modifications for success. I\xe2\x80\x99ll confess to low hopes for Freddy Garcia to become a regular, but also believe Jair Jurrjens could well do it. There are a host of others in the wings \xe2\x80\x93 their names are familiar to Orioles fans \xe2\x80\x93 and one or two of them are going to figure out how to contribute. And likewise with relievers \xe2\x80\xa6 there is no reason to not see the bullpen as among the best in the sport \xe2\x80\x93 even with some recent shellings.There is no doubt that the 2013 Orioles remain a much improved offensive club over last year. But the best of opposing pitchers, when having a good day, will certainly slow them down; but that is true for even the very best teams. It is gratifying to see the Orioles making some moves to send Ryan Flaherty out to AAA to work on his hitting, while also bringing in a player like Danny Valencia \xe2\x80\x93 who has been stroking the ball well in recent weeks.I am looking for all of these troubles to turn around in short order. Baseball is an oft frustrating sport. The margins are narrow. Pitch placement is critical, and a broken bat flare can sometimes land just out of reach and change the entire game. The best hitters fail 65-70% of the time. But it all tends to even out over the course of 162 games, and three-quarters of the season remains. So, slowly step back from the panic button. ', 'birdswatcher.com'), ('Orioles-Rays game demonstrates need for expanded instant ...', '/* Javascript deferred */var addthis_options = "digg, twitter, facebook, stumbleupon, delicious, friendfeed, buzz, slashdot, reddit, mixx, fark, linkedin, aim, google, myspace, newsvine, technorati, tumblr, typepad, wordpress, more";var addthis_exclude = "print";var addthis_pub     = "archivedigger";/* Javascript deferred */Orioles-Rays game demonstrates need for expanded instant replayMatt Joyce\'s fly ball in sixth inning brought game to standstillMay 19, 2013|Kevin CowherdIn the end, the umpires got the call right.But it sure took long enough. And a rough five-game homestand for the Orioles got even rougher in the sixth inning Sunday when Tampa Bay\'s Matt Joyce hit a soaring fly ball down the right field line in the Rays\' eventual 3-1 win.That\'s when all the fun started.Actually, it was only fun if your idea of a good time is a long game delay while both managers and all four umpires yak endlessly about whether Joyce\'s shot was a foul ball, a double or a homer. var adSkipCounter = 0; Trust me, the Geneva Convention guidelines were hammered out in less time. And you wonder why Major League Baseball is hurriedly trying to implement expanded instant replay review for next season?In a moment, we\'ll get into that. But first let\'s recap all the, ahem, action in the top of the sixth at Camden Yards.With one out, Joyce hits a shot that glances off the base of the foul pole in right field. After a moment\'s hesitation, first base ump Dan Iassogna rules it a fair ball and Joyce legs it into second base.Out pops Buck Showalter from the O\'s dugout. He argues that it\'s a foul ball."That\'s what some of my players felt strongly about," Showalter said later.Seconds later, though, instant replay is clearly showing the ball hit the black base of the pole. It\'s definitely a home run. Now Rays manager Joe Maddon comes out to argue.And the gabfest is on.Maddon\'s stalling for time, waiting for his people to tell him if it\'s a homer or a double. By rule, only a home run is reviewable as to whether a ball is fair or foul. Maddon, the umps will say later, wants the play reviewed, but only if the consequence isn\'t the possibility of it being ruled a foul ball.Got that? Maddon wants the ruling to be either a homer or a double. He wants, metaphorically speaking, a Lamborghini or, at the very least, a Mercedes.No dice, say the umps. If we review it and see it\'s a foul ball, it\'s a foul ball.But ... let Showalter pick up the Maddon strategy at this point."Maddon\'s waiting for some kind of feedback on what kind of argument he\'s got," Showalter said. "He\'s gotta make a decision on whether he wants [the umpires] to go check it or not [on instant replay]. \'Cause he\'s got a chance that [they] go in there and end up calling it a foul ball, and not even a double."So you gotta make that decision on whether you want to roll the dice for the home run. So when he got all the reports back from his people, I\'m sure he felt real confident on what was gonna be called. I have a [instant replay] guy who lets me know when I have a good argument. So I knew once [the umps] went inside [to review], it was gonna be a home run."Which it was. The umps got it right, Showalter said. That was the main thing.But all the confusion and the endless yammering that preceeded the correct ruling is why you\'ll almost definitely see expanded replay review next season."I think you\'re going to see a lot more replays as we go forward in the game," Showalter said. "You\'re going to see more than just home runs reviewed. So you know I\'m all for it, just getting it right."And I think the umpires are, too. They want to be right. More times than not, they are."MLB sources now are saying that balls and strikes won\'t be reviewable by replay next season, but almost everything else will.Commissioner Bud Selig seems to leaning this way, too. In the past, Selig has made it clear he thinks instant replay should only be used to determine home run calls or whether a ball is trapped in the field.But these same sources say Selig has been embarrassed by all the blown calls and umpiring controversies of late. And they say he\'s now leaning toward broader use of instant replay.Look, I was originally one of those Luddites who argued against replay review in baseball. I thought the calls would take too long to make and disrupt the natural rhythm of the game.But guess what? The game is being disrupted enough as it is, even without expanded review. I don\'t know how long Sunday\'s delay was, but it was at least 10 or 15 minutes. So now I\'m thinking baseball should implement the best video technology possible and give expanded instant replay a try.Heck, it can\'t get be any worse than what we\'re seeing right now.Can it?kevin.cowherd@baltsun.comtwitter.com/kevincowherdsunListen to Kevin Cowherd Tuesdays at 7:20 a.m. on 105.7 The Fan\'s "The Norris and Davis Show."     window._taboola = window._taboola || [];   _taboola.push({     mode: \'thumbnails-f\',     container: \'taboola-below-article-thumbnails---archives\',     placement: \'Below Article Thumbnails - Archives\',     target_type: \'mix\'   });  MORE:Whether a stent is needed can be tough callWhy expansion tank is needed\'Blushing\' ear is no cause for alarm7 Ways Michael Jackson Changed The WorldCivil War wasn\'t to end slavery Purposes: The South fought to defend slavery. The North\'s focus was not to end slavery but to preserve the union. The slavery apology debate misses these facts.A tragic case of contradictions Slaying: A father and daughter\'s first outing alone would be their last. Police say Richard Nicolas killed 2-year-old Aja, but friends say they\'re certain he didn\'t. ', 'articles.baltimoresun.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94  Roughly a quarter of the way through the season, Manager Joe Girardi has managed to hold the Yankees together with the baseball equivalent of duct tape and bubble gum. Still without the many injured stars who fill out his roster, and now armed with a diminished version of C. C. Sabathia, Girardi has leaned on a collection of lesser lights who have had a knack for producing.It was more of the same Monday in their 6-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles, as players like Lyle Overbay and David Adams helped set the stage for Vernon Wells, who drove in the go-ahead run in the 10th inning with a ground-rule double. Then again, some things never change, with Mariano Rivera recording his 625th career save.\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no quit,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said of his team. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re excited to get to the ballpark every day, and they\xe2\x80\x99re finding ways to win.\xe2\x80\x9dIt was a resilient effort by the Yankees. Travis Hafner tied the game in the top of the ninth with a solo home run off Orioles closer Jim Johnson, who blew his third straight save opportunity, and Adams went 2 for 4 with his first major league home run. He also made some fine defensive plays at third base, which helped the Yankees offset another spotty start from Sabathia, who allowed four runs in six and a third innings. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cTo be thrown in here, with the tradition and they history they have \xe2\x80\x94 they expect to win every game, and I understand that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adams, who was recalled from Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre last week. \xe2\x80\x9cSo for me, I\xe2\x80\x99m just trying to work as hard as I can.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  As for Sabathia, the first pitch he threw was a fastball that registered at 90 miles per hour. It was not exactly slow, but it was not vintage Sabathia, and this has become a theme for the Yankees. With reduced velocity, Sabathia has been forced to rely on guile and pitch location to try to outwit opponents. Sometimes, it works. Sometimes, it does not. On Monday, he gave up 11 hits and struck out just two.\xe2\x80\x9cI was ahead of a lot of guys, and just didn\xe2\x80\x99t make the pitches,\xe2\x80\x9d Sabathia said, adding that he thought he left too many balls up in the strike zone, especially late in his outing . \xe2\x80\x9cIt was one of those days.\xe2\x80\x9d Photo       Yankees pitcher C.C. Sabathia allowed four runs in six and a third innings.  Credit             Patrick Semansky/Associated Press           The Yankees gave Sabathia a 3-2 lead in the top of the seventh when Overbay blasted a solo homer off reliever Troy Patton. But Sabathia could not hold it. In the bottom of the inning, he allowed run-scoring doubles to Nick Markakis and J. J. Hardy.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Both hits came on off-speed pitches. Markakis clobbered an 81-m.p.h. slider, and Hardy got his bat on an 83-m.p.h. changeup. Sabathia no longer possesses a huge gap in velocity between his fastball and his off-speed pitches, and hitters seem to be having greater success against him as a result. Because his fastball is no longer quite so fast, his slower stuff no longer appears quite so slow.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cHe left some sliders up, and they were home runs and doubles,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I thought he battled all night. He gave us a chance.\xe2\x80\x9d [{"headline":"Sports","summary":"Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, delivered to your inbox every week.","product-code":"SP","product-title":"Sports","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/sports?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=SP&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Race\\/Related Newsletter","summary":"Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with New York Times journalists.","product-code":"RR","product-title":"Race Related","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/race-related?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=RR&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Your Money","summary":"Every week, get tips on retirement, paying for college, credit cards and the right way to invest.","product-code":"MY","product-title":"Your Money","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/your-money?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=business&contentId=MY&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"}]      Please verify you\'re not a robot by clicking the box. Privacy Policy    The Orioles turned to the veteran right-hander Freddy Garcia, who introduced himself to his former teammates by allowing three hits and two runs in six innings. He helped himself by inducing two inning-ending double plays.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  After spending the 2011 and 2012 seasons with the Yankees, Garcia, 36, started this season with Class AAA Norfolk and showed enough promise for the Orioles penciled him into the rotation. His first three starts were forgettable. He had a 5.51 earned run average with two losses and a no-decision, having lost the ability to retire left-handed hitters with regularity. Girardi took note of this before Monday\xe2\x80\x99s game and packed his lineup with seven left-handed hitters.But aside from giving up two early home runs \xe2\x80\x94 solo shots to Robinson Cano and Adams \xe2\x80\x94 Garcia flummoxed the Yankees.Sabathia had no such success. The Orioles tied the game at 2-2 in the fifth when Steve Pearce led off with a double and Markakis drove him in with a single. Like Davis, Markakis made solid contact with a slider. \xe2\x80\x9cI just couldn\xe2\x80\x99t put guys away,\xe2\x80\x9d Sabathia said.Still, the Yankees have persevered to vault themselves to the top of the American League East. Before Monday\xe2\x80\x99s game, Girardi recalled the season\xe2\x80\x99s opening week, when the Yankees lost four of their first five. Mark Teixeira, Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and Curtis Granderson were sidelined with various ailments, and Girardi was being peppered with questions about how he planned to repair a crumbling clubhouse.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve said all along that I\xe2\x80\x99m proud of what these guys have done,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think there were so many question marks about how we were going to put it together, and it\xe2\x80\x99s just kind of normal now. It\xe2\x80\x99s a normal baseball season. It\xe2\x80\x99s a grind, and you\xe2\x80\x99re going through it every day.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on May 21, 2013, on Page B15 of the New York edition with the headline: Sabathia Has a So-So Outing, but New Players Come Through Again. Related Coverage          REDS 4, METS 3   Mets Keep It Close but Fall to Reds MAY 20, 2013                       ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('Orioles GIFs of the Week - Camden Chat', " It's Monday again, and Orioles fans desperately need to get our minds off actual baseball, fraught with sadness and bitter disappointment. Viewing and voting on GIFs improves one's general sense of well-being and the feeling of being in control of one's personal destiny, according to an unpublished study by this writer. Let's get to it! Place your mouse over the GIFs to activate. Vote for your favorite below HAMMEL VS DUBBLE BUBBLE   One of the many valued members of the Camden Chat community pointed out that this one was missing from last week's GIF roundup. It turns out that this is even more appropriate for this week. Thanks 3r1c. CASILLA WANTS HIS FIST BUMP   A third base coach has a number of responsibilities - sending or holding runners, relaying signs, telling runners when to tag up, and so on. Another one is that he must give a runner a fist bump when he reaches third base. A runner is entitled to a bump even if he advances from second to third on a GIDP. If you steal second and scramble to third on the same play, putting the go-ahead run 90ft from home, and get your jersey dirty in the process then damn right you get a fist bump. Bobby Dickerson was derelict in his duty in this instance, to the point where Alexi Casilla was forced to insist. He eventually obliged with a half-hearted, distracted bump. Sheesh. That's nearly as egregious as withholding a home run hand-shake/high-five/fist-bump with optional butt pat.    ADAM JONES CATCH  Look at that! There were actually some good things that happened, including Gold Glove CF Adam Jones robbing a possible home run. Also see Chris Tillman's reaction.    MANNY PLAYS HARD TO GET   If you want that out you're going to have to chase Manny for it. Turns out that Manny wasn't just trolling the Padres here because Steve Pearce was rounding third and crossed home plate a few moments after the out was recorded. Allowing the runner to score would have produced another clip for the Extreme Heads Up Baseball with Manny Machado video compilation. Didn't quite work so it just landed in the LOLs bin. ANOTHER THOR HOME RUN   Let's end on a positive note - Chris Davis crushing a ball with a pink bat.    That's it for this week. Don't forget to vote below. Follow @OriolesGIFs for all of the GIF action all week long. Retweet some stuff. Send me your requests by tweeting at that handle. Thanks for watching!  ", 'www.camdenchat.com'), ('Orioles Notable Quotables - May 20th', 'Another game, another tough loss. While this one may be remembered for yet another \xe2\x80\x9cwas or was that not a home run?\xe2\x80\x9d the fact is, the O\xe2\x80\x99s have lost five straight, and while it\xe2\x80\x99s a little early to be hitting the panic button (this team is young, all things considered, average age of 27.9), I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d check in with the Twitter vibe about the O\xe2\x80\x99s. Below are a few notable quotables from the past couple of days.\xc2\xa0Freddy Garcia said he\xe2\x80\x99s done all his work in between starts to start on schedule on Monday. Buck hasn\xe2\x80\x99t announced starter yet. #orioles\xe2\x80\x94 Eduardo A. Encina (@EddieInTheYard) May 19, 2013\xc2\xa0O\xe2\x80\x99s have 3 quality starts in last 10 games- all by Chris Tillman. O\xe2\x80\x99s 1-2 in those games b/c blown save in one & lack of runs in other.\xe2\x80\x94 Mark Viviano (@MarkViviano) May 19, 2013\xc2\xa0Time to clean it up. Pretty simple yet extremely difficult #StayHungry\xe2\x80\x94 Adam Jones (@SimplyAJ10) May 19, 2013\xc2\xa0I\xe2\x80\x99m glad my positivity runs off on ppl. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to be negative in this world. Rise above and smile\xe2\x80\x94 Adam Jones (@SimplyAJ10) May 19, 2013\xc2\xa0But clean it up in the process. Always a constant process in life. Aim for greatness\xe2\x80\x94 Adam Jones (@SimplyAJ10) May 19, 2013\xc2\xa0Showalter hoping Flaherty can \xe2\x80\x98get his legs back under him\xe2\x80\x99 at Norfolk sns.mx/6ksMy7\xe2\x80\x94 Matt Wieters (@MattWietersFans) May 20, 2013\xc2\xa0Freddy Garcia will start tmrw, Buck said.\xe2\x80\x94 Eduardo A. Encina (@EddieInTheYard) May 19, 2013\xc2\xa0This is a tough stretch, 53 games into the season and heading into the hot summer months. The offense and the pitching have both had stretches where they\xe2\x80\x99ve been superior, maybe just not necessarily at the same time. Look at the positives, though. According to ESPN.com, the Orioles are 3rd in runs scored (212), 5th in slugging percentage (.440) and 5th in team batting average (.267), continuing the team-wide improvement. Pitching has been dealing with injuries and lack of a consistency starting rotation, but Jim Johnson has been (almost) lights out. Tomorrow, the team is in primetime on Monday Night Baseball at home against CC Sabathia & the division-leading Yankees, it\xe2\x80\x99s a solid chance for players to shake off the tough start to the homestand and finish May on an upswing.Ending on a fun note, the 13th seeded Orioles are in the finals(!) of the ESPN.com Battle of the Uniforms. They\xe2\x80\x99re facing off against the top NL seed St. Louis Cardinals after knocking off the top AL seed Tigers and the 2nd seed Yankees. Like Jim Caple said, \xe2\x80\x9cAs fans of the comedy series \xe2\x80\x9cPortlandia\xe2\x80\x9d know, the secret to merchandising is to slap a bird on it. And apparently, the same holds true for baseball uniforms.\xe2\x80\x9d Here\xe2\x80\x99s the link, vote O\xe2\x80\x99s!Battle of the MLB Uniforms\xc2\xa0 ', 'birdswatcher.com'), ('Baltimore Orioles: The best things that happened in the ...', 'Everyone knows the Orioles are slumping.\xc2\xa0 It is an unavoidable fact that even good teams do go through losing streaks.\xc2\xa0 To this point, the Orioles really have not played their best baseball, and yet they are still very much in the thick of things.Among other pieces of good news for the struggling Birds, Pedro Strop has been pitching much better recently. Mandatory Credit: Joy R. Absalon-USA TODAY SportsDespite the fact that they are just 3-7 in their last 10 games, there are some positive signs that could point to a change in luck for the O\xe2\x80\x99s.Pedro Strop is pitching much betterPedro Strop seemed to lose his way towards the end of last season.\xc2\xa0 While he pitched well in the World Baseball Classic for the champion team from the Dominican Republic, he has been unreliable and wild through the first 4-5 weeks of this season.\xc2\xa0 Strop seems to have turned it around a bit, allowing only 1 run in his last 13 appearances.\xc2\xa0 He\xe2\x80\x99s throwing more strikes, keeping the ball down, and his confidence is clearly up.J.J. Hardy is finally hittingJJ Hardy\xe2\x80\x99s bat has been asleep for most of the last year.\xc2\xa0 In the last week he\xe2\x80\x99s gone 8 for 23 (.348 BA) with 3 RBI.\xc2\xa0 Instead of letting out a collective sigh when Hardy comes to bat, lately O\xe2\x80\x99s fans have been excited to see this guy step into the batter\xe2\x80\x99s box.AAA Norfolk call-ups are making an impactThe bats of Chris Dickerson, Yamaico Navarro (as compared to Ryan Flaherty at least) and most recently Danny Valencia are exciting to watch.\xc2\xa0 With the early season injury to Brian Roberts, and the lack of production from Oriole DHs, a bit more pop has really lacked from the bottom of the order.\xc2\xa0 Perhaps one or more of these Norfolk additions will end up making a solid impact.Miguel Gonzalez returns to the mound on TuesdayAfter being sidelined since May 3, Miguel Gonzalez will make his first start in nearly 3 weeks on Tuesday.\xc2\xa0 Gonzalez had much success against the Yankees last season, and he hopes to return to last year\xe2\x80\x99s form tomorrow night.\xc2\xa0 While he has not blamed the blister on his right thumb for his early season inconsistencies, O\xe2\x80\x99s fans are hopeful for a turnaround on Tuesday night.\xc2\xa0 Gonzalez has looked great at points this season, and less than stellar at other times.Feeling any better O\xe2\x80\x99s fans?\xc2\xa0 This too, will pass. ', 'birdswatcher.com'), ('Orioles Lose To Yankees 6-4, Skid Reaches 6 \\xab CBS Baltimore', ' BALTIMORE (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 One big reason for the Baltimore Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 success last season was Jim Johnson, who led the majors with 51 saves and was as reliable as an expensive watch. After a solid start this season, Johnson is struggling. Not coincidentally, so are the Orioles. Johnson blew his third straight save opportunity Monday night, and Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s losing streak reached six games with a 10-inning, 6-4 loss to the New York Yankees. New York trailed 4-3 in the ninth before Travis Hafner homered with one out on a 3-1 pitch from Johnson, who converted a franchise-record 35 successive save opportunities before his current slide. All three of those botched saves have come during Baltimore\xe2\x80\x99s current skid. \xe2\x80\x9cThe other guys do their job and I do mine, then we\xe2\x80\x99re not standing here,\xe2\x80\x9d Johnson said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think everybody\xe2\x80\x99s doing a great job. I\xe2\x80\x99m just not pulling my weight. And I\xe2\x80\x99ll figure it out.\xe2\x80\x9d Johnson wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the only culprit. Starter Freddy Garcia allowed two homers and Troy Patton gave up one. \xe2\x80\x9cWe had trouble keeping the ball in the ballpark,\xe2\x80\x9d Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. Robinson Cano hit his team-high 13th home run in the first inning, David Adams clubbed his first major-league homer in the second and Lyle Overbay connected in the seventh. And then there was Hafner, who got hold of a fastball that was way too high in the strike zone. \xe2\x80\x9cHe had one bad pitch,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. In the 10th, Ichiro Suzuki led off with a double off Pedro Strop (0-2) and Vernon Wells followed with an RBI double to left. Hafner\xe2\x80\x99s two-out single made it 6-4. David Robertson (3-0) worked the ninth and Mariano Rivera got three straight outs for his 17th save in 17 tries. Johnson was 15 for 15 at one point. Now he\xe2\x80\x99s 15 for 18 after blowing save attempts against San Diego, Tampa Bay and the Yankees. \xe2\x80\x9cThe ball\xe2\x80\x99s up. That seems to be the common thing lately,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cJust not making the adjustment. I\xe2\x80\x99m trying, you know, doing everything. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to work through it.\xe2\x80\x9d After Overbay put New York up 3-2 in the seventh, Baltimore took the lead against Yankees starter CC Sabathia in the bottom half. Alexi Casilla singled and scored on a double by Nick Markakis, who came home on an opposite-field double to right by J.J. Hardy. Showalter elevated Hardy to the third spot in the lineup because the shortstop came in with a .321 career batting average against Sabathia. Hardy also doubled in the fifth against the big left-hander. Sabathia gave up four runs and 11 hits in 6 1-3 innings. He left with New York trailing 4-3, but Hafner\xe2\x80\x99s shot in the ninth preserved Sabathia\xe2\x80\x99s 17-4 lifetime record against Baltimore. Garcia, who pitched the past two years for the Yankees, allowed two runs, three hits \xe2\x80\x94 two homers and a meaningless single \xe2\x80\x94 in six innings. Aided by two double plays, the right-hander faced only three batters over the minimum. After Cano and Adams provided the Yankees with a 2-0 lead, Chris Davis hit his 13th homer for Baltimore in the second to make it 2-1. Garcia retired eight straight batters before Adams singled in the fifth. He was erased by a double play. After wasting a two-out double by Matt Wieters in the fourth, Baltimore pulled even in the fifth. Steve Pearce hit a leadoff double and scored on a single by Markakis. Later in the inning, Sabathia retired Adam Jones on a grounder with runners at second and third. Replays indicated first base umpire Eric Cooper got two calls wrong in the sixth inning, both of which went against Baltimore. Brett Gardner appeared to be picked off first base and was called safe, and Wieters seemed to beat out an infield hit but was called out. NOTES: Orioles RHP Miguel Gonzalez (blister on thumb) will return from the disabled list Tuesday night and start against the Yankees, who will have right-hander Phil Hughes on the mound. Hughes yielded seven earned runs in the first inning of his last start, against Seattle. \xe2\x80\xa6 Yankees 1B Mark Teixeira batted in a simulated game in Florida, testing his injured wrist for the first time since spring training. Also, 3B Kevin Youkilis (spine) took batting practice and fielded ground balls; 3B Alex Rodriguez (hip surgery) fielded grounders; INF Eduardo Nunez (oblique) did dry swinging and also took grounders; and RHP Ivan Nova threw 60 pitches in extended spring training. \xe2\x80\x9cAll our guys are increasing their activity. Everything is on the up and up a bit,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\xa6 Washington Capitals forward Brooks Laich threw out the ceremonial first pitch. \xe2\x80\xa6 Suzuki extended his hitting streak at Camden Yards to 20 games. (Copyright 2013 by The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.)  var addthis_product = \'wpp-261\'; var addthis_config = {"data_track_clickback":true};if (typeof(addthis_share) == "undefined"){ addthis_share = {"url_transforms":{"shorten":{"twitter":"bitly"}},"shorteners":{"bitly":{"login":"cbslocal","apiKey":"R_bfe2742f79bb4091b0fcfbdf5c6a81ca"}}};}  ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94  Phil Hughes confronted the fading memory of his last start by taking the mound Tuesday night at Camden Yards and throwing four straight fastballs. For much of his herky-jerky season, it had been a pitch with extreme results. Unhittable one start and uncontrollable the next, the Hughes fastball had been as fickle as a windblown paper airplane. It has been a painstaking quest for him to prove he can throw it and produce results.So he approached his start against the Baltimore Orioles hoping to regain his rhythm. And though he never felt completely comfortable in the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 3-2 loss, especially coming out of his windup, he said he was encouraged that he was able to work through trouble.\xe2\x80\x9cHopefully I can take some steps forward from this one,\xe2\x80\x9d Hughes said.The Orioles ended a six-game losing streak when Nate McLouth hit a game-winning homer off reliever Vidal Nuno in the 10th inning. It was a rare miscue from the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 bullpen. Nuno said he wanted to throw a cut fastball away from McLouth. It did not cut enough.\xe2\x80\x9cHe took advantage,\xe2\x80\x9d Nuno said.Hughes gave the Yankees six strong innings. He allowed five hits and two runs, while striking out five. He made two mistakes, surrendering two solo home runs to Chris Dickerson. Hughes did not figure in the decision, but his effort was cause for optimism amid an otherwise disappointing night for the Yankees. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m encouraged,\xe2\x80\x9d Manager Joe Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cHughesy\xe2\x80\x99s run some pretty good streaks for us together. He hit a little rough spot. He\xe2\x80\x99s come out of them before, so there was nothing that led me to believe he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come out of it again.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Facing Seattle last Wednesday, Hughes could not escape the first inning. He gave up seven runs on six hits and two walks before Girardi removed him with two outs. Hughes threw 36 pitches, each with more disastrous consequences than the last. It was, he said, a humbling experience.On Tuesday, Hughes needed only 11 pitches to breeze his way through the first inning. It was clear from the beginning that Hughes wanted to lean on his fastball, though he said before the game that he would turn to his off-speed pitches if he was laboring with his location. Photo       Phil Hughes allowed five hits and two runs, while striking out five Orioles batters.  Credit             Nick Wass/Associated Press           Command has been his biggest challenge this season, particularly early in games. Hughes tends to overthrow, which causes his mechanics to crumble like a sand castle. When that happens, his arm flies loose, outpacing the movement of his lower body, and he releases the ball sooner than he should. The end result is often a fastball that hangs high over the plate, as hittable as a pi\xc3\xb1ata. Hughes described these pitches as \xe2\x80\x9cmistakes.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  He made one in the third against Dickerson. He tried to get Dickerson to chase a two-strike slider, but Dickerson let the pitch pass for a ball. On the 10th pitch of the at-bat, Hughes uncorked a fastball that he left up over the outer half of the plate. Dickerson sent it over the wall in center.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The damage could have been worse. Later in the inning, Adam Jones flied out to the warning track with two outs and two on. Center fielder Brett Gardner made the catch with about two feet to spare. Such was the razor-thin margin between a solid start for Hughes and a potentially disastrous one. Privacy Policy    \xe2\x80\x9cI got out of a few situations,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.Travis Hafner, the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 designated hitter, accounted for the team\xe2\x80\x99s runs with two run-scoring singles off Baltimore starter Miguel Gonzalez. Aside from those miscues, though, Gonzalez sailed along and went seven innings.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  It is a rare occasion, Girardi said, when a pitcher has all his best stuff working. More often, he will need to make adjustments. Girardi cited the right-hander Hiroki Kuroda, who has a knack for surviving even when he loses the feel for his slider. In Hughes\xe2\x80\x99s case, he might need to mix in more sliders and changeups when his fastball misbehaves. Girardi said he had no choice but to trust that Hughes would know when to alter his approach.\xe2\x80\x9cYou can try to enforce it, but the enforcer is standing there with the baseball in his hand,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said, adding, \xe2\x80\x9cIt falls upon his shoulders.\xe2\x80\x9dHughes was not impenetrable \xe2\x80\x94 he allowed four leadoff hitters to reach base \xe2\x80\x94 but he persevered. The fifth inning featured Dickerson\xe2\x80\x99s second homer, a comebacker off the bat of Manny Machado and an error on shortstop Jayson Nix, which left two runners on base with one out. Hughes avoided trouble by striking out Nick Markakis and inducing an inning-ending groundout by Jones.\xe2\x80\x9cThat was an inning when I had to grind and battle out of a tough spot,\xe2\x80\x9d Hughes said.It was that sort of night for Hughes: good enough to give the Yankees a chance, even if it was one they squandered. ', 'www.yahoo.com'), ('Orioles Beat Yankees 3-2 In 10 Innings To End 6-Game \\u2026', ' BALTIMORE (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 The shaving cream was still glopped on Chris Dickerson\xe2\x80\x99s head and shoulders long after the final pitch, a tell-tale indicator that the Baltimore Orioles had finally returned to celebratory mode at Camden Yards. Nate McLouth homered leading off the bottom of the 10th inning, Dickerson hit a pair of solo shots and the Orioles beat the New York Yankees 3-2 Tuesday night to snap a six-game losing streak. McLouth hit a 1-1 pitch from Vidal Nuno (1-1) into the bleachers in right-center to give the Orioles their first win since May 12.\xc2\xa0 Dickerson, who played sparingly for the Yankees in each of the past two seasons, connected off Phil Hughes in the third and fifth innings \xe2\x80\x94 the first two-homer game of his career. For their efforts, McLouth and Dickerson each got a shaving cream pie from teammate Adam Jones during their postgame interviews. It was a fitting way to mark the end of a skid in which all six defeats came at home. \xe2\x80\x9cWe really needed this win,\xe2\x80\x9d Dickerson said. \xe2\x80\x9cThis team continues to grind, continues to push forward even when the chips are down. Nate came up huge. This was one of those things that can turn it around.\xe2\x80\x9d Asked if it was the best night of his baseball career, Dickerson quickly replied, \xe2\x80\x9cAbsolutely. Under the circumstances, yeah. \xe2\x80\xa6 As soon as I saw the lineup card I was already fired up, just to get the opportunity to play against them. But to go out and have that result, it was awesome.\xe2\x80\x9d Jim Johnson (2-4), who blew three save opportunities during the six-game skid, got three straight outs in the 10th. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just happy about the outcome of the game,\xe2\x80\x9d Johnson said. His performance capped an exceptional effort by Orioles pitchers, who retired 21 of the last 22 New York batters. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was nice to win, period,\xe2\x80\x9d manager Buck Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnytime, regardless of yesterday and the day before. We don\xe2\x80\x99t get bogged down in that woe is me and this means that. You\xe2\x80\x99ve got to keep turning the page.\xe2\x80\x9d Travis Hafner drove in both runs for the Yankees, who fell to 19-1 when scoring first. Dickerson\xe2\x80\x99s role in New York\xe2\x80\x99s defeat did not go unnoticed by manager Joe Girardi. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve had him up a couple times and he\xe2\x80\x99s done some good things for us,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe helped them tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d Hughes allowed two runs and five hits in six innings. Coming off a horrid start against Seattle in which the right-hander yielded seven runs and got only two outs, Hughes kept the Orioles in check \xe2\x80\x94 except for Dickerson. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought he did OK,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe gave us a great chance to win the game.\xe2\x80\x9d Both bullpens matched zeroes until Nuno threw his third pitch. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was supposed to be a cutter away,\xe2\x80\x9d the left-hander said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt felt a little bit off and he took advantage of it. One pitch and it cost us the game. Got to forget about it and get ready to pitch tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d Baltimore starter Miguel Gonzalez gave up two runs and five hits over seven innings, striking out five and walking none. The right-hander came off the disabled list before the game following an 18-day absence with a blister on his right thumb. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was fun to be out there again after two weeks being out and giving a chance to my team to win a ballgame,\xe2\x80\x9d Gonzalez said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think that was fun, especially getting ahead of guys. That was important.\xe2\x80\x9d New York got a first-inning run when Brett Gardner doubled and scored on a two-out single by Hafner. Dickerson tied it with a drive to right-center on a 3-2 pitch. The Yankees quickly moved back in front. Vernon Wells led off the fourth with a double and Hafner followed with an RBI single. Dickerson\xe2\x80\x99s second homer of the game, leading off the fifth, made it 2-all. Gonzalez retired 11 straight batters before David Adams singled with two outs in the seventh. Lance Nix followed with a liner that right fielder Nick Markakis snagged with a dive. NOTES: To clear a roster spot for Gonzalez, the Orioles optioned RHP Jair Jurrjens to Triple-A Norfolk. Jurrjens started one game for Baltimore, receiving a no-decision Saturday against Tampa Bay. \xe2\x80\xa6RHP Hiroki Kuroda will start for New York on Wednesday night in the finale of the three-game series. The Orioles will start Jason Hammel, who is 0-2 with a 7.79 ERA in three home starts. \xe2\x80\xa6 Yankees manager Joe Girardi said SS Derek Jeter (left ankle) \xe2\x80\x9cis not really doing anything yet\xe2\x80\x9d and LHP Andy Pettitte (strained trapezius muscle) has not starting throwing. \xe2\x80\xa6 Orioles C Matt Wieters turned 27 on Tuesday.
